content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												I just want to say that this game used to be incredibly good. In all honesty I've played more of Awesomenauts than any other game I've played to date. This game is a MOBA like any other, but with rather simplistic mechanics compared to other MOBAs. Things like shop items are limited to a small variety that can drastically change the style of play of characters, very unique to other MOBA shop items that merely provide stat changes. Despite being a "Watered-down" MOBA, the game was very fun to play.As the years carried on, however, the game began to quickly lose its sheen. Ronimo has failed to listen to its fanbase time and time again. The matchmaking system now is the same as it was when it was first released: Without relative skill matchmaking, so matches are often decided before they even start. No dedicated servers, so networking in the game is strictly peer-to-peer, which doesn't work well with MOBAs. All forms of hit detection are determined by the client of the attacking player, so a lagging player can easily rack of kills by exploiting his latency. Game balancing has been an issue, as the stronger characters tend to be the newer ones available through DLC, making things feel P2W at times. The community is awful; expect cancer.Overall, this game had potential, but slowly my expectations for Ronimo to respond to player pleading and continued to take the game in a direction no player wanted.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												Almost 600 hours played and first review ever.Nauts was a fantastic game. The community has good and bad seeds and good and bad players. I, for one, can say I've made a ton of friends that I regularly talk to in Steam even if not playing a game together.The new patch completely and utterly destroyed the game. It punishes poorer team comps, slower build team comps, and non-premades. Never have I seen a game that REFUSES to let you win if you have 1 poor performer on the team. You can't save them or carry them -- they literally cause the enemy team to be on God Mode. Worse, I can't even enjoy it. If I play with a premade, we steamroll the other team. There's no competition; there's no chance of a comeback. If I'm playing a premade, there's no hope. We will be steamrolled. It's a zergfest. Get 3 initial kills and 0 deaths as a team, basically auto-win button. I HATE rage quitters, but what is the incentive to even stay in matches if you're guaranteed to lose?Worse, why didn't Ronimo listen to the community? Who infleunced this misguided ship?If you want a mass exodus, by all means -- keep the game the same; If you want to create competition and engagement -- change it. If you're trying to stop turtling, perhaps nauts who refuse to leave their turret for 60 seconds start taking a 'Death DoT'. If, XP is your bread and butter, then remove all damage dealing skills and make everything about building characters to different utility functions. Better yet, bring 2.12 back and create an XP system in Nauts 2 that you have time to test and understand without public outcry. We did not want this. I have sadly, uninstalled the game. Best of luck Ronimo.

												You will play solo vs a premade.You will play vs vastly better opponents every single time when you have a lesser experienced player on your team.You will win 50 games to get 10 ranks only to lose them thanks to a single losing late join.You will play vs Australians, Chinese, Madagascarians, Martians and other beings from distant worlds which will deal damage to you and kill you with a swell 5 second delay - no dodging for you!You will play solo vs a premade.You will get frustrated, start adding people to play together, and they will join - without asking - the opposing team!You will play vs a dude who keeps taunting, deserved or not, like he bound his left mouse button to the function, you will turn off the game sound forever only to keep seeing "Enemy taunts you!" written in big letters on your screen regardless!You will face imbalance, questionable design choices and constant quirks that emerge after every hotfix only to be left in for weeks after appearing.You will trashtalk, swear, learn sarcasm, be sarcastic, learn bitterness, be bitter, learn saltiness, be salty, you will overcome that, stop being toxic and still shout at your monitor - "WHAT THE F**CK?".You will keep getting invited to out of region games by that one dude who added you out of the blue even though you told him you can't handle the ping.You will premake and play vs players who haven't yet figured out which button is which skill.You will have fun, or hope you will next match, because it will be challenging, or at least, fair, or at least, i don't know? There will be a next match, won't there?But would i do it all over again?

Posted: November 4, 2014
												A constant love-hate relationship characterizes the gameplay of pretty much everyone that has played awesomenauts competetively. Scanning the game's official forum tells you why. This is a beautiful game that is marred by some flaws. A 2-D side scrolling moba with an array of characters greet you when you play this game.Pros- Beautifully drawn characters and environment.- New updates every 1-2 months.- 19 awesomenauts to choose from. - 4 maps and different game play modes.- Replay system / Tournaments.- Great for casual play in leagues 3-9.Cons- Horrible matchmaking.- A disconnect will drop you 200 ranks.- If you're in a premade with good team members you can pretty much stomp everyone.- If you play solo you'll get to league 2 or the bottom of league 1 and matchmaking will eventually drop you a couple of ranks.- Sucks for competitive play.- Those who play on the worldwide network (like me) will be matched against those that want to play within their region. This causes a lot of friction in the community. Most Asians can deal with the lag but others cannot.The reason I stopped playing this game was because I was tired of facing only 2 possible outcomes1. You play in a premade and no one can stop you. Stomp Stomp Stomp.2. You play solo and you get matched against duo or premades and your teams mates are in league 3-5.The game is awesome and you should check it out. As long as you do not take it seriously / competitively you'll love it. Fair competitive play is only possible with manual matchmaking.

												I have roughly 800 hours into this game and now ill uninstall it, AGAIN.The core game is really great, characters are great, artstyle etc.So I was hoping for change since it would be worth it.The sad truth is that its unplayable 80% of the time.Lags and disconnects are one of the biggest issue. Without dedicated servers there WILL BE NOT WAY to get rid of this. NO WAY TO PLAY THIS COMPETETIVELY!!!!!! This destroys about half the games you play since either your lucky and your enemy has the leaver / lagger or the whole game is unplayable with 300 ping favouring some chars which benefit from lag.The community is not excatly what youd call friendly so be prepared for ragequitters and lots of flames.Matchmaking does not feel to be balanced but this could be because there are very few players playing the game (as a result of the above mentioned) so often the matches are very unbalanced. This results in even fewer people playing etc...Combine all this and you have, again, a situation where you simply wont have fun playing this 80% of the time. If it works, its a good game. I cannot recommend it, sadly, and going to uninstall now and maybe forever.Come back when there are dedicated servers which will never happen because devs focus on new nauts and skins.Its a sad story of a good game taking forever to try to be playable but never achieved it, I wont waste any more time on this and neither should you, sorry :(Edit: Now even "migrating host" results in disonnect 50% of the time, besides other major bugs. Cant change this review to positive even with the new patch. Bugs and Servers still break this game.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
Disclaimer:Please don't feel offended by my review. We all have different opinions and there's no reason to fight over it. If you don't agree with me, that's fine. I'm not trying to convince you to change the way you feel about the game. This is just my opinion.Review:With close to 1300 hours played over two accounts I used to love this game. A simplistic side scrolling MOBA that's very easy to get into, what's not to like? A lot of time was spent in the game, I made friends and we had lots of fun. Unfortunately, as time passed the flaws of the game were revealed.This game actually favors people with poor internet connections and if you don't have a bad internet connection you might as well simulate one to gain unfair advantage over your opponents. How is this possible? Due to Ronimo being a small company they can't really supply dedicated servers so they designed the game for p2p networking. You have the option to queue in different regions, same or nearby would be recommended. It doesn't matter though, if someone feels the need to queue worldwide (maybe because lack of players) they can join you no matter what your settings are. It gets frustrating real fast playing an opponent with over 300 ms of latency. They can actually pick a naut that favours their ping to get the upper hand because it gets impossible to dodge certain skills because you can't anticipate where a projectile might be on their screen and before you know it you've been hit. If someone choose to queue worldwide you'd think it'd be more of a challenge for them because of latency but it's really the other way around.And if they don't have high latency they might have packet loss and that can actually trigger effects on abilities multiple times. There's a naut that has the ability to pull other nauts to him using his tongue, if the player has packet loss he can actually tongue you multiple times and this is very frustrating. His client registers that he hit his ability but the packet was lost and had to be sent again and maybe a few more times.The design wouldn't be so awful if both players had a say in the matter and dedicated servers would make it even better and actually favor players playing on the right side of the globe.Networking issues aside, the matchmaking could also use some work. Solo queuing is ok but can be a terrible experience since players can just leave the game without any ramifications. If the player hosting the game crashes and the host migration fails everyone gets a loss. Some maps end in single lanes which makes a choke point and favors nauts that can turtle and just delay the game for as long as possible.edit:I quit playing this game because it was actually making me rage. I still occasionally play the game for the sake of ongoing tournaments and to keep in touch with the friends I made along the way. The game still has flaws, some of them being addressed (slowly). Until all of the major issues have been resolved I will not recommend this game.It's a lot of fun to play when the stars align, but whenever people lag (be it due to connectivity issues or if it's intentional) it ruins the experience completely.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												My playtime in this game is probably enough to tell you tell that I've really enjoyed it. Awesomenauts is a MOBA played in 2D . I picked the game up a few years ago and I still find the game fun to play.At the start of a match you pick a character. You have the usual classes you find in MOBA:s, such as rogue, tank, support and so on. Every character has their own set of skills and items you get to pick from at the start of the match. Characters and items are unlocked as you level up your account, which is fairly easy to do and comes naturally as you play. The characters in the game all look great I think and they really fit the flippant feel of the game. As always there are some balancing issues for a time after a new character is released, but for the most part the characters are pretty well balanced and only your skills determine how tough a fight is going to be, not bad balancing. You will learn how to play most of the characters pretty quickly although there are some characters that require more practice to master them, as is common in most games like Awesomenauts. It wouldn't be much fun otherwise. The ease of learning the basics of the game means that you can get into it pretty quickly and with so many characters with very different playstyles you will want to try them out and in this game you're able to do that in very little time.Matches usually last about 20-30 minutes and if a player disconnects from the match then another player can immediately jump into the game, which is something that I really like about the matchmaking system in Awesomenauts. The possibility to join ongoing games means that a team where a player disconnects isn't necessarily crippled, as is often the case in other MOBA:s. To win a match your team needs to destroy the enemy team's base. To do that you have to push through one or two lanes where turrets need to be destroyed in order to process further. Nothing out of the ordinary here. Mobility plays a big role in Awesomenauts. Not all characters are fast and not all characters have skills that help them escape. This means that when you play as the slower characters, typically the tanks, you will need some knowledge of the layout of a map in order to be able to escape. The importance of mobility is something I really like about the game.I think that the larger part of the community is pretty friendly, but that could just be because most players tend to not say anything in matches. Ragequitting is very common (or at least it was back when I still played) but other than that you'll probably not have any problems with other players.TL;DR: I would definitely recommend Awesomenauts to people who like this kind of games. Just watch a few videos of it and you should be able to tell if you would enjoy it.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Replayability: As of writing this review, Awesomenauts has stolen over 750 hours of my free time, and it is bound to rob me for many years to come. With the multiple match ups (meaning how good certain characters are against other certain characters, on a scale of equal player skill) no session has ever felt the same.Arenas: I cannot compare it to the likes of DOTA or LoL, since I havent played either, but coming from someone whos played the likes of Powerstone 2 for the Dreamcast, I can tell you that this game offers a robust experience. The arenas are structured in such a way that allow you to go miles by taking an inch. Characters: The prime beef. Ronimo takes a bit of slack when it comes to balancing certain character traits and abilities, half of which I would say are very much deserved, but at the end of the day using the character in a way that outplays your opponents strengths and capitalizes on there weaknesses will outrule any match up against you. You are bound to find a character, if not half the cast, to your liking~Single Player: There is none. This game will not engage you if not played online. Future DLC will patch in alot of match customizablity, so I cant say much on how they will integrate it, but not including the Starstorm DLC, I would not reccomend this game to anyone who is timid of the online environment.Art: The game is advertised to look and sound like a Saturday morning cartoon. The Musical Score matches this, with catchy rhythmic beats that loop in the background and character specific that play ala reward for killing sprees. The graphics, not so much. Dont get me wrong, the sprites are colorful (albiet small in relation to everything else on screen, but still packed with personality) and the levels looks gorgously bright and tell a story, but the only thing "Saturday Cartoon" about it is the intro video and character portraits. Still, you get what you get, and if youre a fan of the child friendly art style, you wont be disappointed.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Awesomenauts is based on the premise of casual competition. It is designed to be fun. An interesting result of that is the lack of a real consequence when somebody quits your team. He is replaced by a bot that is often more competent than himself and continues to play in his stead. Another player can join mid-game to replace the bot at any time.Awesomenauts also has a great community (official forum, not Steam). It has a thriving fanart community, a modding one, a tactics one, etc.This game really opens itself up to modders. It allows creators to modify in-game bots and make their own using an AI editor. Modders can also create gamemodes using this tool. If Ronimo likes a bot, it can find its way into the official game.Overall, I highly recommend Awesomenauts. It has a thriving community that you should not miss out on. The gameplay is very fun, if less competitive than its other MOBA counterparts. All that is lacking is you.

												A truly amazing game. The imagination of the developers is wonderful and they have a great sense of humour and the way they have put this game together as an indie developer is nothing short of excellent. The gameplay is reminiscent of Super Smash Bros, and is an instant recommend for anyone who enjoys that series. Like Smash Bros. it is both light-hearted fun and can be very competitive, easy to learn and hard to master.There are problems, however. Balancing a multiplayer game can be difficult and is never perfect, and the maps do have some annoying gimmicks. The matchmaking and Leaderboards are kind of broken and are meaningless to most, don't let that get to you and random teammates can be bad mannered.But, I believe the core game is worth it 20 times over the problems, and would suggest anyone to give it a try!

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
Note: If you DO NOT live in an European or American region, the matchmaking system will be hard to tolerate in this game. Now that patch 3.3 is out, I've had enough time to get my opinion on the update everyone was waiting forAwesomenauts is a fast paced 2D side scrolling MOBA with 26 character (soon to be 27) all of which have unique & interesting playstyles. I never could get into MOBAs such as DOTA or LOL as I'm not keen on the RTS genre. When this game first came out, it was a breath of fresh air into MOBAs & I really like the idea of a side scrolling MOBA as it's one of my favorite genres. I'll start of with what I liked about the gamePositives: - Great artwork- Catching music- 2D platforming MOBA (I honestly really wanted to play a 2D sidescroller MOBA)- All characters have difficulty levels to indicate new players on their choicesIssues & problems the game has suffered fromI really liked this game when it first came out & I really want to play it now but ultimately the downfall of this game is the negatives of this game which is a combination of A LOT of factors. Now before I go into these negatives, I'll give you a summary.- Bad paywall system & why it can't even be free to play- Lag & connection issues- The terrible matchmaking system prior to update 3.3- Devs & the community- Rapidly decreasing playerbase- The Overdrive update (game's last chance in a sense)- Where we're at nowHorriffic bad paywall system & why it can't ever be free to playYou know the big well known MOBAs like DOTA & LOL are free to play? Well it would make sense in a marketing view to make a lesser MOBA free right!...Right? No? Oh, ok then...You'll have a very tough time standing out then. Oh well, at least you get ALL the characters when you buy it rather than 2 DLC containing 33% of characters which cost just as much & is the same price as the game-Oh wait WHAT!? Goddamit...Maybe you should wait unti it's free to play? Sadly, this game can't go F2P despite how much I want it, no system in place to keep you staying (e.g. free premium skins for playing long enough or an in-game economy), player numbers don't go that higher during F2P periods making a super huge risk the devs just can't afford to take. Lag & connection issuesThe company that made this game are independent developers so they don't have the most amount of time, resources & money to make a MOBA as big as DOTA/LOL. They made this game peer-to-peer as it was not feasible to host servers which means that if you're playing with someone with a huge ping indifference it REALLY changes the game & usually for the worst. Just watch this & you'll understand. I can understand why they used the peer to peer model, game wouldn't exist if they used another method.


YouTube™ Video: Awesomenauts - Lag is OP 

			Views: 1,021		

			A demonstration of what lag can be like. The only video editing done to the clips was to block names and add text. Nothing was done to make the lag seem worse than it was in the match.		

The matchmaking system was terrible beforeIf you've gone through reviews written last year, it's no surprise the majority of them talk about the shotty match making system (both good & bad). Remember the ping indifference? You had NO SAY what so ever if laggy people joined your game and there were so many huge skill gaps between teams matches, it was sad most of the time.  Devs & the communtiyThe community wanted a better matchmaking system (which is now patch 3.3) but the devs took a really long time, I mean a REALLY long time then they release the EXP system (patch 2.13) & it wasn't well received by the community. Patch 2,13 made a lot of players  take a hiatus until the new system was introduced. The bad matchmaking, EXP system & overdue constantly being pushed back new matchmaking is what hit this game hard the most between devs & players. Majority of community thought that the devs didn't listen & were interested in skins only.  The truth is that they were working super hard on it but being indie REALLY made it hard, the new system we have now was originally meant to here 1 year ago! Overdrive update:Now this was the update everyone was waiting for, like the second coming of Jesus for this game & when it dropped, current play base TRIPLED in numbers on that mouth, No more screwing around, devs promises that THIS update would have the match making system (& ultimately it was) but when it happened, people were♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ When Overdrive happened , there was no new matchmaking system! Turns out it was pushed back to patch 3.3 & this isn't fully the devs fault but they could of communicated it better. Unfortunately this was the finally nail in the coffin for the vast majority of veterans wanting to get back into Awesomenauts.Where we're at nowNow that the new matchmaking system is out, it's better don't get me wrong bad but it does have its downfall . One of the issues the playerbase were point out in both the forums is that the match making system is POINTLESS if they're aren't enough players participating & should introduce a F2P period for this game when it happens (they didn't FYI). Oh crap, turns out it was actually true. When this update happened, I rarely notice the difference in the old system, I'm still getting match with people far away from me because I don't live in Europe or America and player numbers JUST BARELY raised. Now it's safe to assume that Awesomenauts is at the end of its lifespan. The only thing left going for it is going F2P but it's either never happening or won't happen until a couple more years.Patch 2.13 - December 02 2015 (EXP system)Patch 3.0 - March 02 2016 (Overdrive)http://steamcharts.com/app/204300Well...That's it. I've uninstalled it & requested a permanban that I ask to never be lifted...I'm sad, you know? I really wanted Awesomenauts to succeed, spent $30 on skins but it just wasn't meant to be. At this point, only play it casually & with friends. Thanks for reading & have a good one.

number of helpful: 107 of 154 people (69%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Okay, first thing's first: I hate MOBAs.I really hate them. The fantasy/myth/RPG styled theme, all the nonsense you need to cram into your brain faster than forgetting to study for a test and doing it last minute (I personally can tolerate that kind of stuff, but not with MOBAs) and the hostile communities make me hate them. Hate's a strong word, too. However, Awesomenauts is a significant turn for the better. Although the online multiplayer has its share of issues, Awesomenauts stands out from the rest and is what MOBAs should be like.GraphicsThe graphics are cartoon-like, with a cheerful (yet dark at the same time) atmosphere. No fantasy stuff here, Awesomenauts is a sci-fi theme and that's something worth seeing after the same old MOBA. I love the visuals for the game, and I see nothing wrong with them.GameplayThe gameplay is simpler at first for the rookie MOBA player. Shoot stuff, (attacking without abilities has a bit of a meaning now, hooray!) use your abilities to get an edge over the other 'Nauts, and much more. But then, when you get into it, you'll start analyzing your playstyle to suit your needs with that 'Naut, how to take on the opponent in a one-on-one, and more. Although I did experience significant amounts of lag that costed me quite a few deaths and also really bad matchmaking, the gameplay is still solid to me.StoryThe story is simple and straightforward. You play as an Awesomenaut (or Lonestar in the tutorial) and you need to destroy the enemy's Solar drill. Solar is crucial to your employer for an unknown reason, and you need to destroy the drill so you hinder the enemy's Solar supply. MOBAs are known for their lore, and although this game lacks lore compared to other MOBAs, Awesomenauts doesn't fit in the category of a fantasy/RPG world like this.AudioThe audio is probably the key point to the game. The music (especially the theme song, just play the trailer if you haven't done so already) is outstanding, and the themes really get into your head. My personal favorite themes are Froggy G, Yuri, and the new character Scoop. The voice actors did an OUTSTANDING job with playing the characters and don't seem all bold or shrouded like most MOBAs do. Each one has their own personality that makes them unique from the others, and if I'm not mistaken, popular Youtuber TotalBiscuit even voiced one of the characters (Vinnie and Spike I believe) which I found pretty interesting. The audio overall to this game is near perfection, and I feel empty inside without those "awesome" songs.ReplayabilityThe replayability is pretty massive. I don't want to touch up here much because it's a MOBA. Its easy to get hundreds of hours logged onto a MOBA.For one thing though, Awesomenauts has some major pros that don't fit into any of the five main categories. The developers are dedicated, for one. They constantly release updates and even do some charity work. Check out Lonestar's Private Mels (?) skin. A kid came in from the Make-a-Wish Foundation and made his own skin for his favorite Awesomenaut. The updates keep on rolling in, and the most recent (as of this review anyway, 2.7 in case you're wondering) introduces Scoop, buffed every character in the game, gained a new main menu, and so much more it's better I keep my mouth shut. One more thing though that sets Awesomenauts apart from the rest is that the community is much, much, MUCH nicer compared to the other MOBAs. You don't get yelled at for screwing up, you actually GET help when you need it, and so Awesomenauts makes me feel comfortable when I get on.VerdictIn the end, Awesomenauts may be in my least favorite game genre, but who cares? Awesomenauts still got a thumbs-up from me. Aside from a few online flaws, Awesomenauts is a game that fails to disappoint me, and is one amazing adventure not worth missing.Graphics- 9.5/10Gameplay- 7.5/10Story- 7/10Audio- 10/10Replayability- 9.0/10.:8.0/10:.+Nice community+Caring developers+Outstanding voice acting+Unique style, executed well+Catchy theme song +Easy to learn but hard to master gameplay done right+Awesome cast of characters+Unique character themes-Lags frequently-Awful matchmaking-Ranking is meaningless

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												I'm sad to add my hat to the pile of negative reviews. Awesomenauts always had a unique sort of charm to it. It's likely the first online game I invested hundreds of hours of my life playing. Ronimo were also the first developers that I really wanted to support. I followed all the streams, bought nearly all the skins as they released and gave 50 bucks to the Starstorm kickstarter.Unfortunately it's nowhere near as charming as it used to be. The UI used to have character and life to it and the devs kept "updating" it by removing or streamlining features. The shop redesign was the first thing to make me raise an eyebrow. Awesomenauts used to display all the items in a vending machine kind of setup where you could view all the colorful artwork for each upgrade. It clearly had a lot of love put into it. The new "improved" shop system was a transluctent sci-fi styled pull out menu with much tinier icons. While I understand Ronimo wanted to expand the amount of items per row from 3 to 6, they could have just drawn more space in between. There have been many other minor UI changes but that was the most saddening to see.On top of the life being drained from it, I have a lot of issues with the XP system they introduced back in September. That was the final straw for me. I tried for months to play the game anyway figuring it'd grow on me. It did not. I still can't fathom why Ronimo broke their own game so badly. Snowballing matches happened occasionally under the old system, but after XP was introduced they skyrocketed. The solar drops and respawn time on kills were already strong enough ways to gain advantage, but no. That wasn't enough. Now teams gain buffs to damage and health too! Ronimo also stated their intent was to speed up matches that took too long but that wasn't ever an issue to begin with. My most memorable matches were longer ones where the leading team changed back and forth. Games are way too short now and it's much harder to have a match you feel was worth the time spent.The XP system patch also needlessly complicated other parts of the game. Ronimo multiplied all health and damage numbers by 10 to make it seem like you were doing more. The problem with this is that every number displayed now has 1 extra digit. You can imagine how much this gets in the way during gameplay. I could tell day 1 that hindering every players view of the match was in no way a good enough tradeoff for bigger numbers. Sure you adjust to it but there was really no point in changing it to begin with. Reverting it could only improve on the issue, after all.You also used to be able to read how much damage you'd gain for taking an upgrade but the added percentage increases with the XP system make this old method impossible. Instead, every upgrade now states the increase as a percentage. This isn't user-friendly at all. In such a fast paced game where you need to be spending as little time as possible browsing the shop, it's incredibly difficult to tell at a glance how effective an upgrade will be when it's displayed as a percentage. I used to be able to see that I'd get 25 (now 250) extra damage per stage. Now your guess is as good as mine, unless you want to be bothered to calculate percentages as your turret continues to be shredded. I don't need to know the exact numbers sure, but a ballpark figure of what I'm capable of dealing would certainly be appreciated. Again with time you could memorize what does what. However, each character added to the roster makes this more and more of a headache.I sympathize with the developers. I really do. After putting in so much time and effort on a complete overhaul to the game's mechanics, it would be a colossal waste to revert the changes. That's the issue. Ronimo has its hands tied and can't as a company justify going back to the previous system. Unfortunately the game has to suffer for it. I had many great times with Awesomenauts but I cannot recommend this game anymore.

												FInally getting round to writing a review on this game. Ive played since the very beginning, across all platforms (Xbox 360, then PS3 then PS4 and finally PC). It has the groundwork of a great game, its just a shame it has been driven into the ground. From a team desperately trying to keep it afloat and make money off of it, who care more about making purchasable skins and adding P2W Nauts then actually making an enjoyable playable experience. This game has been out for YEARS, literally YEARS and it has 5 maps......5!! This game needs to be retired, I would be more than happy if they just shelved it and brought the Characters over to a new game and tried something completely different. For one 3v3 is dreadful, if you have one bad team mate, 90% of the time you arent going to win no matter how well you play. It's been plagued with server issues since day 1, its rife with laggy games and questionable hit boxes, funnily enough I have just switched in on for the first time in a couple of months to find they have released ANOTHER new naut (still the same old 5 maps though) and first game i try to get into (after a 7 minute queue time) hangs up at tha Character select screen and crashes. I gave it 10 mins, tried again, this time making it into the match only for a team mate to DC after 2 mins, followed by me a couple of mins later. I finally managed to get back into the game only for them to destroy my base while I am in the drop pod. But yeah, "Awesome" job guys, hastag sarcasm.Edit: Just thought i would update this. Nauts was recently on sale meaning a fair amount of new players bought the game. Thanks to Ronimo's "awsome" match making system, you can and will very readily get paired up with or against them, regardless of what League you are in. So there you are, finally in a game after a 7 min queue and one of you team mates hasnt got the slightest clue what he is doing, and just gets repeatedly destroyed 10 times in a row before quitting out of the game. Ahhhhh Ronimo, you are so clueless about your own game it is borderline offensive.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
												Don't buy this. I say this with a heavy heart, because the game used to be fun. It had enormous potential as a new take on MOBAs. I used to really believe that. I even still believed it could be resurrected despite a rapidly dwindling player base and veterans fleeing the game left and right over the last years. I'm a sucker for a good redemption story.Alas, despite the incredibly long time they took to develop their new matchmaking (codename "Galactron" - game version 3.3), which many of us remaining players thought might turn this ship around, I am now forced to conclude that devs did not manage to fix the problems at the core of this game. In fact, as of right now, it's worse than ever.So, to put all this in context, let the nice uncle tell you a story about how things were a while ago. Specifically, what matchmaking used to be like.Basically, it was "first come first served" with very limited regard to how experienced ("skilled") players really are and where they come from ("ping"). Thus it was entirely possible to get matched with/against players from across the globe (literally), or players who had picked up the game barely a week before. This is not hyperbole. This happened way too often for it to be coincidence. I have played this game for close to 3000 hours over the last couple of years (smurf accounts included), so believe me, I've been around the block. It means something when I say: the number of unbearable matches with either extreme latency or extreme inexperience was beyond counting.And it gets better: the devs directly and intentionally caused this situation, as regards high latency. There is/was a setting that let you decide WHERE your game client would look for a match. In other words, you could specify the maximum "distance" (=~ping) that would be acceptable for your matchmaking. Sounds great, no? It would be. Except, devs felt it would be unfair to actually enforce this setting. Unfair to all the people from remote areas of our planet, who would then have a more difficult time getting matches. So they came up with a truly unique solution: The setting only goverend YOUR client. If you set it up to be looking for matches as low ping as possible, that's what YOUR client did. But that didn't prevent OTHER players from setting THEIR clients to "worldwide" and thus join after you, for example. And of course, predictably, that is exactly what happened once out of every, I dont know, 5? 10? matches. Way too much. Did I mention, that the matchmaking ALSO didnt really care too much what rank/rating players had? Sure, it "tried" to get you a somewhat close match, but in reality that meant "no more than 2 leagues apart". A league is HUGE. To consider players 2 leagues apart is frankly a joke. And again, this is exactly what did happen.The old matchmaking had one advantage however. It ran entirely through STEAM. And Steam has a "block all communications with user" feature. After a while, Awesomenauts players figured out that using this would also keep players from getting into one's matches. So that's what we did. My blocklist grew to several thousand people from thousands of miles away. It was the only way to keep matches relatively free from 200+ ping.This worked alright for a while. But the game had other issues (esp. balancing), or not everybody knew about the blocking, or indeed wanted to make use of this "trick", resulting in more and more players becoming fed up with the game. Veterans quit. The game's population got thinner. Matches got worse. It was stomp after stomp after stomp then, and has been for the last year or so. But, at least you could block laggers and terrible players.That is, until now.The latest version - "Galactron", version 3.3 - finally introduced the supposed panacea for this game, the fix that would finally take care of imbalanced skill-matchmaking and horrible pings. Or so we were promised. It was in development for, I dont know, a year or so. It was finally released a few days ago. But already during the preceding public betas it became clear that devs could/would not deliver on their promises. Neither skill-based matchmaking nor ping-based matchmaking has improved for me. I have had to play with inexperienced teammates and against 300ms-players.The difference to before being that they can't be blocked anymore.But hey, as long as devs can develop a new DLC-skin, right? That's one final thing I'd like to mention: Devs of this game have a huge hard-on for graphics. If they put half as much effort into tracking down bugs, fixing matchmaking or getting the game properly balanced, as they put into making new skins and improving visuals, this game could have been a huge hit on the scale of LoL.Based on my considerable experience with this game, I can only regretfully recommend you do NOT buy this. Not even at a reduced price.I for one will keep checking in every now and again, to see if the situation is getting any better, but Im sad to say, it looks like this "final bullet" is a complete dud and my hopes are very low indeed at this point. To say I'm disappointed would be an understatement of some proportion.

Posted: January 14, 2015
												With +900 hours ingame and most of the DLC's,im gonna say something I've never expected to say:This game?I do not recommend it.why? well,wait,Im gonna say the positive things about this game,first the good then the bad,right?+awesome characters+amazing music+great maps+great effects +great artNow,the reasons of why I dont recommend to buy this game (at least for its full price):-Matchmaking,its broken-lack of servers,connection P2P (if steam dies,like every tuesday,every current game dies,and it counts like if you quitted a game)-Drop In system is broken,why? well,Drop In system is a bad idea already,but this game makes you join matches where there's a full premade,and no one in your team,well,its an 1vs3,needless to say that the premade already had advantage and started to destroy every turret-Said system can make you join LOST matches,where the enemy team is already destroying your core (They said its fixed,well let me tell you ITS NOT,I've joined a TON of matches after hte patch that "fixed it" and there were many where I lost as soon as I joined the match)-Did I mentioned the "Region" system? oh wait,I didnt...lets see,since the game lacks servers,the conection between players of a neighbour country can go from 80ms to 400ms,wich in regular servers in other games,playing with the same players only gives you a 10ms pingAlso literally anyone from any country can join YOUR game,that means you can be playing an almost lagless match but then a chinese or a colombian enteres you match,with their 400ms ping RUINING EVERYTHING The game says to have a ping-kick limit,but in my own experience you have to have +550ms to get your kicked by lag,and let me tell you,a 250ms ping is already,ALREADY,unplayable. (People with lag can move freely,killing you while you are behind your turret,because in their screen,you werent behind the turret)-The devs complains that there isnt enough playerbase to fix the matchmaking thingshowever the playerbase is becomen smaller and smaller with every day that passesand the devs denies to make the game f2p,or at least free for a few weeks (just like they did in 2012) So basically the game is having a really low playerbase,which doesnt allow the devs to fix the matchmaking problemsand want to know why the playerbase is becoming smaller? Matchmaking system.Now,I had many,tons of hours of fun,I meet a lot of new friends,I also make fan art for this game,like I said,the "not so functional things" are amazing and that's what attract me the most to this game,but the functional thing that makes it a MOBA is so broken,that I dont recommend to buy it.Its up to you,but if you still want to get the game,go get it somewhere cheaper for steam,9,99$ isnt worth AT ALL.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												If DOTA and LOL isn't your cup of tea, please - try this one. It's unique 2D MOBA centered around aim, map awareness, teamplay and old-school platforming. The plethora of characters with unique, well designed skills (each naut has 2 main skills assigned to 2 buttons + AA, jump and team commands - it's that simple, yet hard to master) and gameplay itself makes this game addictive and ton of fun. You can try different builds, every skill can be upgraded in a different way, same for AA and utility row (movement, more hp, regen etc.). Game is easy to learn, but can be frustrating if you're not paying attention, however there's replay recording built in and you can see what your opponent bought and how he outplayed you.

The community for it has dwindled from what it used to be, every new update just makes the game a little bit more laggy, and the new content the devs keep putting out isn't really worth the money in my opinion. The thumbsdown on this review is based upon the fact that the community for the game is dying out, and for a game that is only online competitive multiplayer you need a fan base to keep it going. I cannot forsee this game lasting another couple years before it is dead altogether.  Queue times trying to find a match are getting longer and longer. You should have bought the game when it first came out if you wanted the true Awesomenauts experience. It is not worth the purchase anymore.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Awesomenauts has fantastic potential, but is not quite there. Tweaks to the balancing and AI will make this one a star.A clever spin on the MOBA genre that strips away the complications and nerdy presentation to create a fast-paced but deceptively complex action strategy game.Awesomenauts has a good and effective mix of genres: platformer, strategy and action. It also has a deep multiplayer with the approachability of a Saturday-morning cartoon.It's surprising just how well the MOBA formula adapts in a 2D environment, it might not be as strategic as others in the genre but it holds its own in terms of how fun the combat is. Special mention also goes to the sound design, very cool soundtrack and each character has their own little jingle, a small touch which I was impressed with, and on top of it all is the great voice acting which adds a welcome layer of charm to an already likebale game. Great concept, great gameplay, much faster-feeling and action-packed than games like LoL or Dota.A brilliant game that's well worth the small price tag.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												Awesomenauts,A fun, casual & cartoonish MOBA that is a blast to play alone and even better with friends. However, the game has a few MAJOR flaws that almost ruin the entire game and cannot be ignored.Cons:-	LOW player base. In a game which is entirely against online players it literally becomes unplayable in non-peak times.-	NO dedicated servers. Causes many lag problems which is further complicated by the game being advantageous towards higher ping.-	UNBALANCED. Many balancing problems, especially every time a DLC is released. Also bad map designs and other problems such as snowballing.-	LATE JOINING. Yes, you heard me right, it is very possible to join a game literally seconds before your team loses.-	All the above problems have turned a once polite player base to salt.Pros:-	When you actually find a game with reasonable ping and non-salty players it can be quite enjoyable.-	Interesting cast of Nauts, no two are the same.-	Music and voice lines are very entertaining and enjoyable.-	Lots of replay-ability, assuming of course you can actually find games.Verdict:A fun, interesting game brought down some rather large problems should have been resolved YEARS ago. If they made the game free and upped the price of DLC the player base would grow and solve the most major problem of being unable to play the game. I cannot recommend this game in it's current state although with a few small changes they could fix the large problems and create a more "awesome" game.Worth getting on sale or if it does go free, if you are in any way serious about MOBAs steer clear.

Posted: June 30, 2016
												Literally a dead game. Game had a good community and was alive pretty well during the era where TotalBiscuit was promoting the game as he lend his voice for Vinnie & Spike.While this game was made back in the day before MOBAs became an all-time high played gaming genre, Awesomenauts was received very well as a fresh and unique game. Which it still is today except for the forced mechanics from similar MOBA's like the EXP (alternatively, the "you will never make a come back") system and other tidbits ("down the throat" competitive) that only did the game more harm than good when there were bigger issues, like stability in games due to peer 2 peer hosting.Now, with MOBAs like Dota 2 and League of Legends being at a very high popularity, Awesomenauts should also adapt in terms of what is paid and what is free. The free characters that are released once in a while are obviously good and are of high quality as other characters, but there is no reason for characters to be behind a pay wall, especially in this current era with games like League of Legends and Smite where you pay for convinience which is skipping the grind to unlock all the champions/gods.Just make the game free to play already or release all the characters for free, Ronimo. While it is obvious that the game should be profitable for it to keep receiving updates, people are not going to take a competitive MOBA-genre game seriously that is pay to play with characters locked behind a paywall. The skins are not the problem, it's the paid content behind a paid game that is a problem for the many of potential new players that will look at this game and turn away or buy it on a sale and never touch it again after playing 1-10 matches. It has only been losing players with some "spikes" during big updates/sales which have been lost at a faster rate than the mentioned spike.[steamcharts.com]

number of helpful: 50 of 67 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												Awesomenauts is a combination of 2D platform/side-scroller with a MOBA (3v3), which creates an interesting combination that turns out as a very enjoyable experience for people who are fond of both genres. Like most 2D platforms,  the main mechanics are simple and it's very intuitive, which makes it easy to learn the basics of the game. It's also similar to 2D platforms in how fast-paced it is, and how much it values reaction times.  However, it also has some of the depth of MOBAs; there are several characters to choose (16 so far and counting), each one with 2 unique abilities and a different set of possible upgrades to choose for your builds and item routes. This combination results in a game that's simple yet fast and competitive. In regards to some specific contents of the game: The developers are active on this game, they produced 15 characters and 4 maps for the base game, plus microtransactions for skins (which doesn't have any impact on the gameplay itself). They'll be releasing an expansion now (currently on beta/early-access) and expand the game from that point on, so if you want to get access to all present and future features (which so far we know are extra characters, maps, spectator mode and custom-setting games), you'll want to buy both the base game and expansion, which is actually really cheap if you buy it on Steam sales or related stuff. The balance of the game is not top-notch but it's pretty good regardless. New players might feel some characters are OP and whatnot, but once you get used to them you'll realise all of them are pretty much playable and none is "game-breaking".There's a big "luck" factor in the game. Players are not forced to play a full game and teams aren't required to be full to start and continue games (which means you can find yourself alone with 2 bots in your team vs 3 human players, although this doesn't happen often). Players are allowed to leave a game (although they'll be punished by losing ranking points), this happens very frequently, specially on losing teams, which can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥for both teams (losing teams with bots frequently have no chance of winning, on the other side, you can be on a winning team and new players will join the game and make a comeback).  You don't know the map you'll be playing either, which is a problem because some characters have a bigger advantage on certain maps. You don't know what characters the enemy picked either. There's no separated queue for premades and solo players, which is also annoying for a lot of people.The game netcode is p2p (so, no servers), this is annoying for a lot of players because you won't experience "input lag" (any actions you'll perform will be instantaneous in your screen), but you will experience a delay in actions of other players (basically you'll see that other enemies will hit you even when it looked like you were out of their attack/skill range). This means that you'll need to deduce the enemy intentions beforehand and estimate the true range of abilities and attacks on your screen based on the player's ping. Finding full matches is not a problem, and there's a decent amount of players online at most hours, so don't worry about buying a dead game (at least not yet!). There are a lot of players who'll want to play with you and it's easy to make "queue buddies".The pool of characters is not as huge as in LoL or DoTA, but all characters have clear differences and they're all fun to play. Character synergy and team-comps are very important and sometimes if you don't pick your character properly you'll find yourself with a team that is incompetent in teamfights or pushing.All in all, I think awesomenauts is a great concept and a very enjoyable game, specially for it's price. It's far from being a masterpiece because of it's issues, but despite that, it's a great experience and you'll have lots of fun playing it, specially if you play with friends.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
												It was a great adventure playing this game for over 2 thousand hours, but now it's time to move on because the game itself is unplayable in its current form.Since this review was posted, I haven't played 'Nauts for a few months (5 maybe). When I left this game, it was already a mess with a new level system that a good portion of the community (and it's not a lot people that still play this game - we'll get there) didn't like, including myself.Why was I still playing a game that was only going downhill? Friends! Yeah, for me, the greatest thing in this game was making friendship, I've met great people and a great portion weren't from the same country as mine, so although lag was an issue, it was still an enjoyable game when you're playing with friends, like any other!I used to play a lot with one particular friend that I've meet on this game, so it was always me playing with him hosting since this game has more or less a 200 peak of players per day, 200 people for a multiplayer is basically a dead game. It's 200 people over the globe, so it's easy to say that the majority of these 200 people are from the USA and I'm not from USA, so i had to deal with all the possible lag. We don't have a lot of games in common, so Awesomenauts was the only choice if we wanted to play together, and now this game literally ended our chances to play together since from the time i went away and didn't play, Ronimo released a major update that only tries to connect you with people from the same country/region. But how am I going to play a multiplayer game with only 200 peak players with people from the same country as mine? If before these changes were already hard to find people to play, now it became impossible.You can check for yourself on steamcharts.com or any third-party website that uses Steam's API to check playerbase from a specific game, to see how many players Awesomenauts have and how it's only a downhill from here (it is for a long time now). Why the developers didn't went F2P on this game it's beyond my imagination, because you could receive a lot more of attention/playerbase going from paid to F2P since they have a great talent designers that make awesome skins already.TL;DR: Want to buy this game to play as couch co-op? By all means, go ahead, it's a great game with great art design and soundtrack to playing with friends. But if you're expecting to play multiplayer online, it's better to search again for other games, this game is dead and it won't change if it doens't go F2P!

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												TL;DRNot recommended with the state of servers now especially if you don't live in US/EU======================================================================After 1,754 hours, from kickstarter to now, it used to be awesome (pardon the pun)to collect all the silly costumes, having all the heroes even having a special ronimo badgeduring game - knowing you were there when it all started...However like having a child, you have no idea how that child will grow up to be - you hope, you prayedyou wished the best for it, but sometimes it turns into awesomenauts and a little piece of you died inside...gee, first thing's first:Not in EU/US? forget about this game, they increasingly made it hard for people to find a matchA STABLE match, not just connect and reconnect sort of match - mind you.with that said:this is an awesome game with 2D elements brought into DOTA/MOBA styled gameplay injected withenough random elements on each levels to keep it interesting.The fact that maps are random and tons of nauts(heroes) WHILE having only 3 nauts(heroes) at any given timeon a team does give this game a ton of variety for how small the game is.Having 3 players per team also made your contribution to the fight much more apparent.Jungling is focused on regaining health most of the time, so you could - should you wish focus on pushingwith occasional jungle to get more health then hop back in the fight.Jungle is also a great place to ambush low health opponents looking for health pick ups.Occasional hazards in each maps keep the flow going from enticing solar induced greed from killing solar boss,fire from the walls, low gravity area, to a literal death void pits and teleportation makes for an interestingflow of battle. Awesomenauts still employ turrets(towers) at certain choke points that still helps peoplewho aren't used to awesomenauts style of gameplay focus on objectives.The nauts (heroes) are also varied with varied fight styles and they are all impactful on every fight.Even a single nauts can be played differently on each match depending on build and what you want to focus on.But with all the praise so far, the management side of things aren't doin too well...they increasingly focus less and less on the things you need to play, I remember back whenthey only had a play button like a literal play button - the connection WAS more stable back then, and noi wasn't playing with ppl near me at the time and it was a ton more stable and far more responsive net codeback then. Now what with "VOLTAR's SERVER" or whatever the name is, it's a lot less responsive, a lot slowerand it's very slow to play a game - i'm sure a ton of old players know what I'm talking about whenyou play a game, YOU JUST PLAY A GAME, not going thru hoops just to play a single game.Sadly with the current state of the game, I dare not reccomend a game - even as brilliant as this WAS, not is.

number of helpful: 43 of 59 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												The way I always try to describe Awesomenauts is as a 2D, action platformer MOBA. Ever since I started playing this game, it's a formula that I truly enjoyed in a way that I didn't enjoy something like LoL of Dota. What sets this game apart, from a mechanical standpoint, is that it has much more emphasis on manual positioning of both characters and skills, and that makes it much more challenging and interesting. Aesthetically it is very stylized and pleasing to see, with bright palets and a very well done soundtrack. The cast of characters is really unique and each has it's own unique skils that make them fun to play. And in my experience, both playing online alone (SoloQ) and coordinated team play are fun. Ronimo is always working on adding new characters, balncing them, and interacting with the community.The only true drawback from this game, in my opinion, is that the community playing it relatively small for a MOBA, which is a real shame. As a result, matchmaking can be problematic sometimes. Finding a match and filling one relatively quick is almost never a problem, but the problem comes in with the difference in skill level of the players in the games.I wholeheartily recommend this game to anyone who wants a different spin on a MOBA, wants a fun game to play with friends, or just wants to play a fun game.I also stream this game semi-frequently if you want to see live gameplay of it: twitch.tv/pyrocheese

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Awesomenauts is a  2D Multiplayer Online Battle Arena, MOBA for short.  This game is available for €10, and offers you lots of fun for that price. You don't have to pay for anything else, except when you want to buy skins for the 15 awesomenauts. These skins are pure cosmetic, they won't give you an advantage in-game. So, what is this game all about? Well, you play as one of the 15 available awesomenauts and you have to destroy the enemy base. Sounds easy right? Well, to do that you have to fight your way through turrets, robotic minions and of course the other team. At the start of the game you try to earn some 'Solar', the gold of Awesomenauts, and buy upgrades for your awesomenaut with it. And you try to kill enemies of course. Unlike MOBAs like Dota or LoL, this game doesn't feature items or a leveling system. Aeesomenauts also doesn't have a laning stage, which means you can be ganked every 30 seconds. After a while, one team will have more upgrades and more Solar than the other team and they will push to the other teams base. And then of course destroy it.Verdict--------Awesomenauts offers a lot of fun, and in beautiful graphics. The game feature's Offline Training and allows you to practice with friends. It also offers ranked matches and 15 awesome awesomenauts.Awesomenauts will keep you behind your computer for at least 75 hours. If you want to collect every upgrade and get Prestige 10, you will be playing Ronimo Games little game for at least 150 hours.Score: 84/100

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												Edit: Another paid expansion was added with more powerful characters locked behind a real money paywall. XP system added that was not necessary and leads to snowballing (the team that starts out ahead will stay ahead now). Playerbase could be toxic at times before, but seems more so now unfortunately. The players want servers not peer to peer player hosted connections, so developers do not add servers, but add powerful pay 2 win characters, more character skins, and an XP system that nobody asked for. End edit.Fun MOBA platformer with large amount of characters. Very good to play with friends.No dedicated servers, every game is hosted peer to peer. Terrible lag can happen often. Matchmaking is ridiculously terribly completely horrible. The top players in the world can be matched against the lowest 30%.The company that makes the game decided to do a kickstarter for a paid expansion. The amount the kickstarter generated exceeded the amount they needed to raise to make the paid expansion by over $200,000 United States currency. They are not adding dedicated servers.The average population of this (online only multiplayer game) on steam is at its lowest point now in april 2014 since 2012. Source: http://steamcharts.com/app/204300#AllAwesomenauts has the potential to be a super fun game that is held back by a dwindling population due to poor matchmaking, no dedicated servers, and a small player base.Personally I have experienced connection problems and random crashes in this game after some patches. These have affected some of my friends as well, but not everyone. They get fixed eventually, but are very annoying.Hope this game goes f2p, and gets dedicated servers, and a bigger playerbase! It was super fun to play in september 2013 when their were 4 times as many people playing as there are now.There are many cosmetic skins available for purchase in this game to provide revenue. Valve increased revenue by 12 times for teamfortress2 after switching to free to play.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												This is a game that honestly had a lot of potential. It's easily capitvating for most new players, the art direction is nice, it has charming characters, and has great music.But Ronimo took it in too many wrong directions. There's numerous balance issues that they've been too blind to fix and when they do actually fix them it creates new issues. Which means the meta is constantly changing and there's always going to be people who abuse this which can occasionally limit who I can safely play. When I'm in higher leagues I don't want to be discouraged from playing certain fun characters just because the enemy team picked an overpowered team composition, because at that point it's not fun anymore, it's just a chore to try to win.Also I would like to point out that there's STILL features from the starstorm expansion that we haven't gotten (Even after releasing the overdrive expansion), and it's been what, 2 years? They hyped up the Starstorm Map so much and said it was gonna be super unique and have all these cool features, and we finally DID get it, but it was a bit underwhelming. It's certainly a well-designed map, but honestly I was expecting a lot more, considering how long it took to actually MAKE it.Then we have the upcoming Happy Matchmaking Server, which is probably their biggest mistake yet. This is the kind of feature that would honestly work if the game had a larger player base, but something like this won't really do much for a player base thats <800. Their goal was to make this game a "casual-friendly" moba, but with the HMS coming up, it's pretty much becoming the opposite. And from what I've seen, the HMS itself doesn't seem to be fixing matchups that much, I've still been running into people across the world and people who are miles ahead/behind me in rank. The HMS as a whole makes me think they just copy-pasted from Overwatch, but forgot that they barely even have a fraction of the players Overwatch has.This is a kind of game you'd probably enjoy every now and then, but don't bother trying to actively play it, it's slowly fading away and Ronimo is too optimistic to see that.

number of helpful: 49 of 74 people (66%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												UPDATED: 4-11-2015Facts: Before I start the review I want to state a fact, so that this review is not entirely based on my opinions. The player base went from 228,886 players in season 5 (Sep. 2013) to its current player base of 24,889 (4-11-2015) for a reason. That is a 920% decrease in the number of players. Also not all of the 24,889 players actually play the game on a regular basis, that is just the number of players that have played at least one match. If you check the reviews on steam most of the negative reviews are written by people who have 200-1000+ hours in the game and used to love playing it. Just keep that in mind before you buy this game.Credentials: I have put over 580 hours into the game as of this review. I am a fairly high tier player and go back and forth between leagues 2 and 3, this means I have a good amount of experience in higher tier matches. First I will list the pros then the cons and then additional information. I do not consider the additional information to be a pro nor a con, I am just providing it for those who are still considering getting this game.PROS:-The graphic art and animations are great, and work well with the side-scrolling nature of this game.-The characters are very unique and have cool abilities that give each character their own personality.-The fighting in this game is very fun, it feels alot like smite had a baby with super mario bros.-The abilities (upgrades) menu is very well done, and allows the player to counterbuild the enemy team.-The leveling in this game is extremely simple. It is based off of collecting solar (currency) for player kills, turret kills, etc. and spending the solar in order to by abilities. This makes the game good for players that are new to this genre of game, and also provides enough complexity to entertain veterans to this genre.-The maps are well made. Each map has a unique feature in its center. For example one map has reduced gravity, one has a giant worm that can kill you, one has an invisibility orb, and one has fire that turns on and off throughout the match.CONS:-The matchmaking system is terrible. As a league 2 player I was frequently matched against players that were league 6-7. There is a huge skill difference between leagues 6/7 and league 2, this made matches boring for me and frustrating for new players. Also the matchmaking system frequently puts players in matches that have already started. It is no fun to join a match in which your team is already loosing by a huge margine.-The game is P2P. Players will constantly get matched against people with bad internet connection. This causes high latency and frequent packet loss. Since some characters do a ton of burst damage, if the player you are fighting has high latency, you can often be killed from 2-3 hit boxes away. The devs have talked about starting dedicated servers; however, they have been talking about it for over a year and still have not done it.-Some characters are inherently better than other characters. This means that you will often play against the same characters over and over again until the next patch makes a different set characters better than the others.-Players can die their way to victory. They do this by attacking the turret until they die, respawning and repeating over and over again. This is able to happen because certian characters do more damage to turrets than other characters. Also the abilities that these characters need to accomplish this are cheaper to get than other abilities.Additional Information:-Matches can last anywhere from 15-45 minutes.-Each character has 4 rows of abilities with 6 abilities in each row. When you buy abilities in the match, you can have a maximum of 3 unique abilities in each row (only 3 out of the 6 for each row of abilities).-The game is 3v3. This is the only option, there is no 2v2 or 5v5 like in some other MOBAs.-You have to aim your abilities with your cursor (or controller), they do not auto hit on click (much like smite).-The prestige system is optional. If you prestige, you loose all of your abilities and have to earn them back again. Some players will love this feature and some will hate it.I hope that this review has been helpful, and has given you a better understanding of what the game is like. I love what this game used to be and it is still very good in some ways; however, until the matchmaking is fixed, dedicated servers are added, and the game is balanced more, I simply cannot recomend this game. If you find this game on sale for $2 or less then it cannot hurt to pick it up. I would love to see the player base go back up and the game to be restored to its past glory.Please feel free to leave comments or questions in the section below, and I will get back to you as soon as possible.UPDATE 11/22/2016Not much has changed with awesomenauts, they have redone the matchmaking system though and it is terrible. Allow me to explain. You now que up for a match and have to wait anywhere from 3-6 mins (on average) to be put into a match. On occasion, i have actually joined a match and then got kicked from the match before I was  even able to choose my character. After i was kicked from the match i was given an error meesage that said "unable to connect to host". I was then prompted that if i did not rejoin the match, i would recieve a loss and been banned from matchmaking for a short period of time. No matter how many times i tried to join the match, i got the same message and was forced to give up and take a loss and time penalty for a match i never even played.TL;DR the new matchmaking system is broken and annoying. Avoid this game if you dont want to deal with the frustration.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												Genre - Cartoon 2D MOBAI purchased this game first a while ago on the Xbox 360 but didn't get around to playing it much. However, when I saw it on a Steam sale I thought I would give it another go.Having grown up in the 80s I find similarities with the music, characters and art style that remind me of the cartoons back in the day. Basically this game is a parody of 80s cartoons and brings with it much nostalgia as a result.The game is a 2D 3v3 MOBA and I think it is probably the best one I have seen, not that many exist to be honest. The characters and abilities are varied and there are several ways to interact with the maps to turn the tide of the battle. I have mainly played Bots at a difficulty I find a challenge  and have enjoyed the many games I have played, even when I lost.You unlock characters and maps as you progress at quite a rapid rate. Then you get to access extra abilities. This encourages you to play more games at once. Against Bots they last 10-20 minutes, which is great if you just want a quick game.It is a fun little game that will be enjoyed by all ages and you can easily increase the skill level if you want more of a challenge.There are costumes to buy and an expansion pack with new characters. The latter is tempting me, but I will see if I can wait for the next sale...

												Owned this game since release, and I've seen it go through many different iterations.I can no longer recommend this game because the developers failed to deliver on multiple fronts:- no dedicated servers, p2p matchmaking is TERRIBLE and the impacts of delay have always been horrid- imbalanced matchmaking for higher ranks because of a dead playerbase - I was routinely in the top 300-500 players when I was active playing back in 2013, and it got to a point where, because I was solo queueing, I could not win games to save my life as they'd be against full rank 1 premades with voice comm.- Starstorm expansion's features haven't been fully implemented, yet Ronimo had the gall to release another paid DLC for the game- Oh, and the addition of the EXP system a few patches ago was the final nail in the coffin. Does nothing to help the snowballing problem this game has always had, in fact it makes it worse because now winning teams can snowball on two fronts - a solar lead (allows you to buy upgrades to your character's kit), AND an xp lead for additional stat increasesSomewhere along the way Ronimo forgot about delivering a quality game and attempted to cash in on what little they've managed to deliver. It's a shame because the art and character style of this game is fantastic. Hopefully one day I can recommend this game again.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Awesomenauts is a 2D platformer/side-scroller MOBA that pits players against each other in 3v3 arenas. It uses a very rich and creative formula that supports a distinctive MOBA experience.The basics of the game are very simple, every character class has two abilities, each assigned to a button of your choice, aside from the basic attack. Your objective, like in most games of this genre, is to destroy the enemy base, and to reach that base you need to get past turrets, which requires creep management and strategy. Killing other players and creeps awards you with Solar, the currency needed to purchase upgrades for your abilities. The gameplay is, therefore, very easy to learn and incredibly hard to master (which keeps things interesting).The similarities with other MOBAs end there. Character classes differ vastly from each other, not only in the abilities they possess, but also in their complex movement traits (some are fast, some are slow, some can jump high, some can hover in the air, others can fly). There is an enourmous variety as each ability's effects and the possible upgrades for each, which can lead to a lot of different possible strategies for a single class.Map design is clever. Currently there are not a lot of them, but clearly each and every map available was well thought of to allow for resourceful use of its elements both offensively and defensively. The map selected for a match can have a very high influence in its outcome, as you may excel in a certain map with a certain class and play poorly in another.The basic game options available are four: The quick match, which randomly selects players based on their League, the Practice mode, that allows you to practice with and against bots, Battle, which allows you invite friends to be your teammates, and Custom Game, which is available only for Starstorm DLC owners, and allows players to create a completely custom match, defining settings like starting solar, creep spawn rate, maximum number of bots allowed, and several other modifiers. Custom Games have two different game modes, aside from the classic mode (destroy the base): Team Deathmatch, which takes the bases away and the ultimate objective of the match itself is scoring kills, and Randomnauts, which is exactly like the classic mode, but each time a player spawns it gets a random awesomenaut with a random build (upgrades are randomly and automatically purchased as Solar is acquired).The audio in this game is superb. Every map has a background music that is slightly different depending on the class you're playing and every character has a theme song, a killstreak song, and a lot of fine voice acting lines. The SFX is also very, very well done. There is a handful of custom announcers available for purchase, as well.Cosmetically, this game features a lot of character skins (premium ones come with custom voice acting) which helps add visual variability to the experience, the only downside being the price (but if you like the game it is a nice way to support the developers!)My general impression is that this game is a must-play, even if you do not like the genre. It is almost guaranteed that you will like it, and even if you don't like, it is certainly worth the try.EDIT: The new party system and matchmaking are, in my opinion, great improvements for what was previously marked by me as downsides of this game, so I have removed those. I feel that the developers have even put quite some effort into tackling the balancing issue, and currently I have really no general complaints.

												I didn't think it was possible, but bad matchmaking got worse.  They just removed a block feature.  On a P2P connection-based game that is unacceptable, especially when your matchmaking pairs people with people from across the globe.  You will never have a good connection with them. Balancing is so shaky (it was already iffy before), but it is clear now that ronimo cannot keep up with all the characters.  Every patch there are clear characters that perform better than others.  People constantly complain about the game being pay2win (which I would argue against (you benefit more from lagging actually)), but now i question that stance with a new ted skin which makes his attack practically invisible.Tons of glitches are present as well (some are hard to tell if it's because of lag or whether Ronimo jsut can't code)The only thing that is worth playing about this game is the gameplay itself, but Ronimo throws every obstacle it can at you to prevent you from experiencing it.
