content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												You die and one of your teammates rq ? Enemy team destroys two turrets and now your base is openHad a bad day and thinking of playing a game? Why not join a late game where your base is at two bars and enemy team is already attacking itYou think enemy naut is far away from you and cannot hit you? Enemy naut uses 500+ ping and it is super effective.You are winning a game? Game crashes and you lose rating anway.Some details:Well, the game is designed for those top 500 or so who are very experienced and when they play, they will play with people within their league who care about their ranking and who won't rq. My rank is somewhere at 1800-2500, it is rare to play a game without an rq. In this game an rq is not a joke, if you die and one of your teammates rq, your base will be open. The design is flawed, there is no pause possible in the game to wait for a new player, so what actually happens, your teammate rq's, a new bot replaces him, two turrets are down, enemy team attacks your base, bot is mid clearing some droids. Then a new player joins. At that point, it is very hard to comeback, the newly joined player, will lose ranking for no reason and you as player, who endured the game so far, will even lose more ranking because the newly joined player gets gold advantage over you (so if one of your teammates feeds and rq's, you get double punished)Well I don't care much about ranking, but when the game disrespects ranking and punishes you for no reason, then ranking starts to lose its meaning and people will rq without caring too much. The game is fun if:-You are among the top ranked players-You play custom games with friends-You play competitive with teammates whom you knowThe game is not fun if:-You are somewhere in the middle (you play from time to time)- You are a player who doesn't rq

number of helpful: 24 of 34 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												Game is fun and great to play to pass the time. Matchmaking	HOWEVER, that does not mean crap when it's your second game and you're put against 3 players that are AND were in the top 10 ranking... 3 times in a row. If you're a new player, this is like Dark Souls but with High Ranking players as the bosses and you dont have any equipment with only 1 game under your belt. Much like Quasso's review, the match making, as the game puts it, is completely "Zorked.""But you only have 10 hours under your belt." Yea, but that's 10 hours of facing players in the top 100 while I have what, 1-20 games under my belt. There was only ONE game where I was placed with people further down the list and even then they were still 1000 ranks above. I was REALLY hoping it was just because the game was trying to figure out where I am on the ranking list but even then after finding out where I placed I still fight the top 100 of thousands."Get gud" Yea because I'm forced to choose 2 things with this game: Spend 100s of hours just to be decent and maybe shadow the higher rank players or just lose 20 games in a row. Winning isn't everything but I'll tell you what, it's not fun losing every game you enter.Even if I continue to play this game, the Community here will just call me out on doing poorly. "I'm new" means nothing to those elitist kids like come on.It's such a huge shame when this game is fun to play but if I can't learn to play it or adapt to these top 100 players play styles then there's no point in me or others turning this game into a "chore." to get better at this game.Until the ranking system is better I haft to agree with the top review. Fun as hell to play especially with friends, but the matchmaking is god aweful. Balancing	As to be expected, the DLC characters have beefier stats than the base characters. This is simply because if there was no true incentive to buy the DLC, then there would be no need to stray from the free characters you get in the first place.This happens all the times in games with DLC characters such as League of Legends. However, League of Legends demand for a new character is often due to his/her new and unique playstyle rather than pure stats. You can still very much outplay some one with a DLC character but they have more leeway with making mistakes and their stats. However, even talking with some experienced players in the top 100, they say their stats are unbalanced but can still be overcome.This goes back to the first issue however. If a more advanced players uses a DLC character, they have the advantage of the stats and skill over just skill itself as it should be.This is a minor issue to be honest but an issue non the less. Client Side Hosting and its problems	Unlike a lot of other games, this game hosts games VIA Peer to Peer server hosting, or client to client hosting. A majority of my games are met with having 400-600 ping (On average, even connecting to someone in the UK from California, I'll have 80 ping at the most!!) and if the host is on the other team, his moves will register just fine while yours will have a delay. This makes skill shot characters almost useless. Some people as hosts can abuse this with something called Lag Switching: A simple program you can set up to purposely put a heavier load on your Modem, giving you higher latency.Also on the rise recently, I have been in a few games that a host has forced others to disconnect through a hangup program or a DDP (Direct Distruption Program) that forces other IPs or connections to disconnect from them (The Host). Ironically, these are the games I have had the best ping with (24-50). I have reported both cases and one has resulted in a VAC ban so at least this problem is being taken care of... at a snail's pace.This ONLY happens with a Client Side hosting system such as in this game. These hackers would haft to DDoS them which is more difficult to do if the game had its own servers.Hopefully I'll play you again later Awesomenauts.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												Before Awesomenauts I have played a little bit of LoL and DOTA2. These games have always been a non-go for me : gameplay too slow (point & click, no way to evade stuff, little skill involved), learning curve too high (you have to read plenty of guides before you can get a handle on what are the good builds, what to buy etc..), and their community usually just suck. Ragequitting, flaming, "competitive" players, you name it.Awesomenauts is the exception.Easy learning curveThis is what kept me playing during my first hours. I did not have to read guides, or to worry about my build - i was just having fun playing this little game. In a few hours only I had understood the basic mechanics of the game.Very fast gameplayJump, shoot, drop, drop, shoot, oh damn there's someone needing help !Take the jump pad, dash towards the enemies, thus saving your mate, and then drop down to jungle and escape. Woosh, you nearly died, but you just saved your mate.Ok, your two buddies are right there in top lane, and you see the 3 enemies standing there. Time to initiate ! You dash, your mates follow, you prevent them from escaping by bodyblocking them while nado'ing.. One is about to espape, you are about to die, but your friend Nibbs just launched her Orb, teleports, and the guy is dead. It's a wipeout. Time to push !And that's basically what the entire game is like. You have no time to rest. You always have something to do, always on your nerves. The slightest mistake might turn the fate of the game.. But you keep playing, you keep pushing. Until victory (or defeat) is achieved.Easy to learn, and yet so hard to masterAfter more than 600 hours in this game, I still did not master 100% of the game.Each one of the 23 characters has a completely different gameplay. That's 23 playstyles to master.  Out of these 23, I think I'm mastering 8 of them. I still have 15 characters to continue learning.. And that's what keeps me playing, even after 600 hours.Epic moments !Be it when you kill someone in air battle, or when you barely escape a gank and manage nevertheless to kill one of them, resulting in a wipeout (all 3 of the enemy team dead) because your team supported you - or when both of your team mates died, but all 3 enemies have low health, and you manage to take them all out..These kind of moments are so rare in the recent games, that Awesomenauts is a perl just for this sake.The consThis game is not perfect though. (no game is)The community still have a couple of weird people. The kind of people that are attracted by the "MOBA" and "F2P" labels. Flamers, ragequitters, ...Matchmaking is not great. But the next big update coming in March should solve this issue.Peer-to-peer system. You can get hit while you're not supposed to on your screen.Final WordsAlong with Rollcage and Freespace, this game is one of the 3 best games I have ever played in my life. I recommend it to anyone who likes 2D games. I got this game in a Humble Bundle, left it in my library, and only played it once a friend reviewed it on Steam..I only wish I had started playing this game sooner

content:
Posted: November 16, 2016
												I'm retiring 'nauts. It's been a little over 2 years that I've been playing this game. I feel like I'm obligated to give a review for the amount of time I've put in, so here it goes:The game itself is great, but it's gone through so much wear and tear that it's impossible for the game to remain pure. When changes are made, people like it or they don't like it. Considering the rate people have been leaving the community, they clearly don't like the changes. Perhaps everyone liked how the game was, when it had defined characteristics, like a peticular set of nauts that gave the game character. It happens to the best of games, shows, etc. It was pretty easy to formulate stradegies and counter teams, but with all the junk being introduced everything now seems worse off than it once was.As of now I don't play anymore, but occasionally see what the community is up to (in forums, fanart, screenshots) for nostalgia's sake. I'd probably play again if Ronimo was able to make some sort of brakethrough that was capable of bringing back the community, such as new balance changes, a line between competitive and casual, different modes for a diverse amount of playing styles, and the list goes on. In fact, I'd love an **implemented** deathmatch or random team deathmatch mode instead of the dumb ones formed in the lobby. I just wish they focused more on those things than spamming new nauts every few months. It would give the game a bit of backbone so people don't just quit from years of frustration to the problems that aren't being fixed.Now to describe my experience: First 50 hours, really enjoyable; 200 hours, kind of fun... and over time it lost it's sting. It shouldn't be a chore to carry teams and do the tedius work of chasing people around and destroying driods.Now the part you want to read: should you buy this game? If it were two years ago, yes (because I liked it back then). However, right now there's really no reason to buy it. No one plays anymore. I'll recommend giving it a try, and whether you like it or not will only be determined when you try it out. There's a lot in store, and much to experience. Like seriously, there is no other game on Steam close to this. Nowhere will you ever find a 2d moba... seriously type that in google images.

number of helpful: 25 of 37 people (68%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												I just really wish there would be an option for a "Mixed" review. This one would surely be one of them.But since this is one of my most favourite games, I rather not hit the "Not recommended" cause that would make me feel bad. Let's say my review is a kind of warning for future players, as I will talk more about the disadvantages rather than the advantages.This game, as the title already says is really, really Awesome, it has tons of potentials, in my eyes it beats Dota2 and even League of Legends (and I like the latter) just to mention the two most popular MOBAs which are kinda similar to Awesomenauts.So the task is, you are in a 3v3 match, you with your two teammates have to defend your base on a battle arena which is also protected by 3 or 4 turrets, that's depending on the map. Both teams have 3-3 (or 4-4) turrets. There are various champions, characters, whichever you call them to choose from, and each and one of them has different, unique abilities. From the medic to the assassin, supports, tanks, you can find different classes, and even these little "types" have different selections. The background story is simple yet still enough for this game, the characters all have their own background stories and the design (even the most of the skins) are also amazing. So, everything is set up for a perfect game, what's wrong then?Pretty much everything else. Sadly.1 . Let's start with the matchmaking. Catastrophy. Horrific. A complete disaster. The game has no dedicated servers, so you pretty much have to wait until the matchmaking finds players from your region (and this one is preferred, or else you have to deal with laggers, and even with this set up you will probably meet them), sometimes it takes like, 5 minutes or even more. And when you are finally in a game which has not started earlier (and will be a losing match as you will get dropped into the place of angry ragequitters), you will probably have to deal with people who have higher ranks than you. And here comes the second most horrible thing;2. The ranking system. I can't describe how it works, because I absolutely don't understand it. You can't choose to play or not play ranked matches like in LoL, you will be categorized into leagues, but the way you level up to higher leagues or get dropped back into the former seems to be really, really random. And if you get into higher leagues because out of your 20 matches you luckily won one, you have to deal with the bigger guys. And by bigger, I pretty much say guys with the highest ranks and prestige, becase those are the ones who I get mostly, even if I am in league 6, with prestige 1. I always, and no joke, always get enemies with max prestige, and league 3-4. Maybe even higher. I don't need to mention how do I end up. 3. The last, and probably the worst thing in this game is the "community", if I can call this a community. I have met a few communities before, but this game definitely has the worse, pretty similar to LoL I'd say. Your teammates calling you noob if you die once, your enemies tapping the taunt button more than M1, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s everywhere, trolls, ragequitters who leave you alone with bots, and enemies still taunting you. During this 70 hours I have met like, 1 or 2 nice random helpful players in this game, seriously. And there is no kickvote or ban system either. 4. I also want to mention how I disagree with the content what you have to pay for. Sure, a few skins to buy them, the devs need to eat something of course (no irony), but there are also characters what you can unlock only with using your debit card, pretty strong characters (I'd not call them p2w though) and instead of a few serious fixes or developing, the company seems to put all their efforts into the new skins and into some occasional bugfixes. Oh, and to nerf Voltar to be almost useless.All in all what I can say about this game is that it is really addicting with its unique humour, gameplay and overall experience, but has so, so many backsides that it might not even be a benefit to play this game. Unless you have nerves made of ropes. I'd suggest the game for people who can be ignorant against trolls, can deal with stress easily, and like this genre.(Also I am sorry for my grammar errors and typos, my English is not the best, and my typing is even worse.)

number of helpful: 40 of 65 people (62%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												This is a hard game to love, but I do. I've sunk far too much time into it to say I don't love it. It can be extremely fun but also very infuriating. It's meant to be a casual side-scrolling Moba / Dota-clone and it does that very well, but when I say casual, I mean super casual. Not caring about winning and game-breaking issues casual. I can handle losing just fine and I couldn't care less about ranking. Being out-played and out-maneuvered comes with any online game. You play until you get better. What I can't handle is losing because you can go 1v3 or the drop-in / drop-out system forcing you to be always down a player because someone forgot they left the oven on and the next person just got a call, so your 3rd is constantly on their way to fight. Or the terrible matchmaking making you join a game where everyone has 300+ ping (yes you can set the game to find only local players but the player base is so small I've had that take 15+ minutes. And then the game is force-started because someone is too impatient). There's issues involving lag even in local region games that have been around since game launch and continue to persist and will forever persist, because the game uses a p2p hosting model instead of a dedicated server. That cost cutting measure is simply awful and I've been dropped out of MANY games where the host decides to leave and we can't all get connected to the new host, sometimes resulting in the entire match being scrapped. I've played the game since almost launch, contributed far too much money to the expansion kickstarter and bought some DLC I didn't care about just to support the devs.  But I've also uninstalled 6-8 times and quit for months at a time because all the issues got to be too much. I usually come back after a big patch rollout hoping some more issues are solved, but more often than not it's simply some unless flair added to the GUI and some balance changes which I can rarely understand the reasoning behind. I've ragged on it a lot and I'm not giving it a thumbs up (in its current state), but I do recommend picking it up, maybe on sale and giving it a shot. Maybe it will have most of my issues with it fixed and if not, at least you can get some good hours out of it.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												One of the most, if not the most casual-friendly Dota-style game on Steam. Play a character, manually aim a shot and help your creeps (droids) travel to the tower (turret), and then destroy the ancient (core) while trying not to die from other players. Similar ideas to Dota/LoL, but great if you're not a fan of the penalty system of more serious games.Would recommend because the updates have helped improve the game IMMENSELY, and there's always something you can learn from the game. As of 2.8, you can bypass the matchmaking problem with the chat rooms in the main menu.The big negatives can be matchmaking, so beware of playing solo. I do it often, but may end up finding random teammates in the chat from now on. Lag can be an issue due to the playerbase, but these issues are from not having millions of people looking for matches at the same time.If you want a more relaxed approach to Dota-style games, or prefer cartoony, unrealistic action multiplayer games, then I would give a strong recomendation!

number of helpful: 94 of 165 people (57%) found this review helpful10 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												The graphics are cute, if you don't mind "cartoonish". The characters are each unique in personality.Hackers/cheaters are relatively rare.The music by Sonic Picnic is exquisite. If you are going to buy anything from this, you should buy the soundtrack.Unfortunately, this is where the fun ends.Matchmaking is terrible, peer2peer technology which means that lag is abound. For some reason the matchmaker is still stuck in 1998 whereas it only offers you to search games by ever-reducing selection (worldwide, continent, local) instead of pairing you with others on the basis of latency/packetloss compatibilities and tolerance.Moreover, the pairing of opponents based upon rank is seemingly non-existent whereas you may face a team of extreme aces with a couple of complete novices for teammates and vice versa, or mixed and so on.Additionally, the game allows late joins. You may be one such lucky 'winner' as to be selected to join a game in progress, for the past twenty minutes, whereas all the players on the team you got tossed onto have quit the game and the opponents been pummeling on bots and becoming superiorly strong for the entire time.You may even rake in the jackpot and join a game that a player has quite precisely five seconds before the base is destroyed and the game is over with a defeat for you (which you WILL take a dive in ranking for).Think of many such fun small joyful defects the game is rife with.Oh, and it is worth of mentioning to note that the community is chokeful with acidic terribly-behaved children (at least mentally). Which, of course, the developers pander to happily.To top it all off, there is no semblence of balance. The disparity becoming fast evident and very wide in scale.With some characters being exquisitely over the top whereas others are scrapping at the bottom. Some of them featuring extremely "cheesy" or "lame" easy methods of combining certain abilities/power-ups to either kill any opponent within mere seconds regardless of their strength/health/abilities or to escape out of any situation essentially becoming unkillable.Some of the strongest characters are also locked behind a DLC pay-wall, effectively turning the game somewhat onto "pay2win" situation.Watching plays as a spectator on youtube is also not very enjoyable, barring the game from any possible future as an e-sports entirely.

number of helpful: 13 of 16 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30
												I've played this game for a few years now and I have always been a fan of the 2d style moba. I loved the unique chatracters and balance that exisited between them. However now this game is nothing like how it shipped. Matchingmaking is just totally unplayable. It is inconceivable to me how they managed to butcher it so badly, like they must have actually tried to make it worse. To even start a game you must wait in a 4 minute or longer queue just to search for a game, no matter how quickly it finds players. Then the actual quality of the matchmaking is just atroucious. I have and always have had an execellent internet connection, but since recently matchmaking updates I consistantly experience a routine lag pause which makes games unplayable as this is a competitive moba. Then theres the leagues which attempt to rank players with similar skill. They never had this right and made it worse than what it was originally. League mobilityhappens too often and 2 or 3 bad match ups can tank your league rating and leads to either easy wins or slightly losing a game. Theres no middle ground which makes games so boring now. You either win easily because your in a lower league than you should be, or you advance then have 1 or 2 bad games and go back down a league. And with Seasons constantly reseting the league your in only the most devouted players experience some remote sense of stability in their rating. I want to love this game again and had high hopes for the big matchmaking update but ut has only made this game worse. Ronimo just keep adding new characters and skins and do not have any real plans on re working this game which so desperately needs it.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
												This game looks cozy and sweet but it is actually a super hardcore, fast paced, team oriented, moba/fighting game. Every naut is unique and most does not follow standard rpg/moba classes. Unlike most mobas this is very much an easy game to learn, there is no need to memorize item combinations and no pregame mumbojumbo. On higher levels buildorders/knowledge is very much still a thing though because of upgrades that happen during the game. Skill ceiling is very high, the pace of this game is fast, not combarable to most mobas, closer to super smash bros, and there are a lot of small mechanical nuances to learn that separates pros from good players and good players from scrubs. Tldr - easy to learn hard to masterSound is easily 10/10, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s of really catchy tunes and effects. The graphical style is eternal if a bit cheesy. The current balance is very fine, sometimes they go overboard with a new naut but it is often reined in a patch or two after release. The game is still in active development and generally patches makes the game deeper/more exciting rather than the dumbing down/shallowness that is popular in most games nowadays. It is possible to turn around a snowball, but it has been made much harder since the xp system (before xp system a single good player could often carry a bad team from a losing position, nowadays it takes an exceptional player or sudden effort from all team-members to carry a bad team. xp system is controversial, personally I think its better with team effort than two titans that have chewed on noobs dominating the pace of the game). Community is varied, a mix of the old breed of good gamers, some trolls, but also some from the hyper sensitive community and rage quitters. Biggest problem is lack of players and as a result matchmaking is a bit ♥♥♥♥ed, the players that are left have a standard of game that is generally higher than in most other mobas.If you are thinking about getting this game then I can recommend keeping a positive attitude/open mind in trying to understand why you are losing. And stay close behind a team-member at all time, preferably someone that doesn´t die, at least until you figure out what is safe.The expansionpacks are fun, but not required to play. Some people think that expansion-nauts are op, but that´s because they don´t know♥♥♥♥♥♥ standard-nauts like froggy, derpl, skoldir, etc are often played or pre-banned in pro-tournaments. All nauts are viable, though most players become comfy with a couple of nauts and stick to them, pros are the same.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												I got this game back in the start of 2015, and it was great. Now, as the recent review for this game have shown, its taken a dark turn.  I've spent over 200 hours on this game and quit like 5 times. The reason, is the games matchmaking. No matter what league you're in, its a guarentee that at one point, you'll be matched against a team of prestiege 10's with two guys that just installed the game. It has apparently been♥♥♥♥♥♥from the very start of this game, and Ronimo has'nt done jackshit. However, they claim that they'll fix it in an upcoming update, so fingers crossed. The community for this game is also very small, not a lot of people know about Awesomenauts, and it doesn't help that the jackasses in it just yell at new players and scare them off, bringing this game down even more. The XP system kinda ruined the most fun part about the game, and that was the long matches in which you couldn't tell which team was winning and the smallest mistake could lose you the game. Now, not only are players rewarded with solar and 1 less team member on death, they get extra damege and health, making it almost impossible to have those types of fun games, turning most matches into one-sided slaughters. I know that this all sound really negative, but let me list the positives of this game. The gameplay is incredibly unique and fun (if you have good teammates) and it's amazing when you're playing with a friend or two. Each character is unique and I feel that there is one suited for everyone's playstyle. The soundtrack for this game is excellent and the art style is unique and colorful. In Conclusion: I've said my piece for this game, I think it's still a good game and worth your time and money, and I sure as hell reccomend it to you. They claim to be fixing the main issues with this game, so there's still hope on the matchmaking being fixed. If you do decide to buy this game, please, stick around and help the community grow, and maybe even leave a good review to help the game appeal to potential new members of this community. Thanks for reading the whole review! :D

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												Before I start, I want to give a heartfelt thanks to Ronimo for what this game used to be.Rewind a good few years, and Awesomenauts was, excuse the pun, an awesome little game. It knew what it wanted to be- it was a little MOBA with a different perspective on the whole thing. Pre-Startstorm (Yes, I mean Starstorm) the game had its true character, with many mechanical differences setting it apart from other games in the genre. Picking which items would be in the shop before the battle was interesting in my opinion- okay, it might not have been a 'good' mechanic, but it gave the game character. And the level system? The level system... Why Ronimo, just why? We had a game that had something to set it out from the masses before from mechanical standpoint. Now we don't even have that. The level system means that a bad start always leads to a bad end- the enemy gets 1 level up from you for more than about 2 minutes and they'll get too far ahead- you won't be able to bounce back unless they choke HARD.Awesomenauts is different from a gameplay standpoint from many of the games in the genre, being 2D, but this is simply the game's shell. Ronimo decided to take the game's soul away a long time ago, and slowly the body has been deteriorating without it. By now, it is simply a husk, lifeless and souless. The matchmaking is broken- reguarly pitting prestige 10 people against those who haven't even unlocked every character yet. I can't tell if that's bad programming or just that Ronimo killed their game a while back, but in any case, right now, in its current state, I have to recommend you stay away from this game.Ronimo? If you read this, could you please give me back Awesomenauts? I'm really not a fan of this new-fangled Awesomenot.

number of helpful: 17 of 26 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												Awesomenauts was once a gem. A bit of dirt and grime on it, but a gem nonetheless. The dirt and grime could have been cleaned off, but update after update the dirt and grime kept building. There'd be something to help clean the gem off, and something to dump it in the mud. But with this recent patch, it is no longer a gem. Ronimo have tarnished it beyond belief with the ideals of aking the game faster, almost outright refusal to fix balence issues the community has been crying out for, and seemingly lack of listening. I have over 1000 hours on Awesomenauts in total. ~700 of which were earned on the Xbox 360. Today, the Xbox 360 version is for more different than the PC version. It was abandoned after only the first update having only two extra characters than the original six. It sits in immense unbalance and it was much more rage endusing than what the PC version was. It was a point of insanely unbalanced characters and upgrades, and the top dogs were extremely obvious, especialy with the small roster it had. I played it constantly becaasue despite it's unbalance it was a gem. It was one of my favorite games period. But after a while the unbalace got to me. The top dogs of the console community were the most imfamous people because they completely abused the unbalance.After some time of Awesomenauts being on the sidelines and my ignoring it, I aquired the PC version.  It was great, so much better than the console version, I loved it so much, regardless of being even barely able to run it due to my horrendus PC. I had regained interest of this gem and I played it constantly, racking up 100 hours in a relatively short time. But then they dropped it in the mud. This most recent patch has ruined the game, dropping a pile of logs on the fire that was the game's unbalance. It already had broken haracters that, regardless of the communities outcry to fix them, Ronimo ignored them and allowed them to remain broken for the most part. Then they added the In Game XP System. This was added to try to make games faster when it could have been more accomplished by many other means. Reworking upgrades and characters, making different maps besides the 3 maps that can be played online. This new Xp system took most of the fun out of the game, removing challenge and fairness. It made it nearly impossible to win a game with a bad start. Before a team, or hell, even ONE player on a team, with enough skill, could make an amazing comeback. Now? The game is decided within the the first 3 minutes. If one team just gets a couple levels ahead of the other early on, they steamroll. They become a snowball of death and misery and it takes all enjoyment out of the game, and makes it nearly impossible to come back by increasing the team's flat health and damage every level they gain, making it harder, and harder, and harder to comeback. This was a terrible idea. As of the current patch, this game is no longer a gem. It is a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ This game was once great and could be again. Ronimo just needs to fix what the community has been wanting fixed. If Ronimo fixes the issues I mentioned here, I urge you to pruchase this game, but in it's current state, I can't say that this is a good game and that you should play it. The only way the game is good at this time is when you have a large pack of friends and play custm games together. The online is ruined by unbalance and attempts to change the game for the "better". But as I said, if they fix the present issues, I could not urge you to get this game enough, but I recommend you avoid it at the current time.

number of helpful: 17 of 26 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
Awesomenauts' flaws hold it back from being a truly awesome game.Pros: Graphics, Sound, GameplayCons: PerformanceAwesomenauts graphics, sounds, and gameplay all mesh well together to create a more casual, faster paced MOBA experience than its 3D brethren.  With only fifteen (nineteen with DLC) awesomenauts, at most two lanes, and one less dimension, the game is more welcoming to newcomers.With no dedicated servers, however, the performance is mediocre.  Disconnects are handled by freezing awesomenauts in place, where they can be killed by enemy creeps or players.  There is no way to reconnect once booted from a game, leaving teammates to fend for themselves with a terrible replacement bot.  Force starts allow premade teams a huge advantage with 3v1s and 3v2s.  Even having a strong connection does not solve the problems if not chosen as host.Overall, Awesomenauts is simply too unreliable to be anywhere near awesome.6/10

												The game was a great, more casual 2D Platformer MOBA that had pretty good depth, but the recent update has ruined the game for me and a lot of other players. Essentially they made all of the characters much weaker, and added a XP system where everytime you get a kill on a player / creep / turret, you get XP to level up. Everytime you level up you're entire team gets a +4% to healh and +4% to DMG. So if a team gets a good start it's almost impossible to come back from. It's not fun for a long time player, and I'm sure it would be even worse for a new player. I would highly advise waiting until this is changed / fixed.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												The game is extremely fun to play. Gameplay is fast paced and brawling with your opponents in a 2d environment with a lot of different abilities extremely entertaining. It requires more skill to master the game mechanics than it seems. The graphics are great, voice cast and sound amazing, lore deep and funny. There is plenty of different heroes to choose from, you will stay occupied for a long time before you become proficient at all of them. The developers update the game all the time, they really try to meet the community's expectations and keep things fresh.However, there are simply too many issues with awesomenauts to recommend it to a new player. Apart from the usual moba complaints (subjective issues like bad balancing, matchmaking, ranking formulas, toxicity of players, etc.) present here, which arent that big of a deal breakers to me, the game suffers because of peer to peer connection system. On top of a rather small active player base its a huge issue.It's common to be constantly matched with players half way around the globe from you. 400 ping enemies is something you will see all the time playing this game. Not only cant you do much to prevent such players from joining your matches (region settings dont work at all, blocking a player on steam doesnt always work and is going away in a future patch it seems) but a lagging player have an upper hand when attacking you. You have to add his ping, so to speak, to all the stun, pull and knockback effects which will move you back to the place on the lagger's monitor during a fight while on your screen you are miles away from danger. The peer to peer connection system works in favour of high ping players which is really unfair to players with stable connection.I play awesomenauts very often and enjoy it, but i have to tell, getting unfair matches most of the time is so frustrating i dont see how new players could enjoy the game now. Moba/2d-platformer mix works so great that it is strange there arent any more mobas like awesomenauts nowadays.

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 19, 2012
												After two-three long years of Awesomenauts, I thought I might give you my full thoughts about this game, now that we are getting close to the end of the Starstorm DLC development and the new Matchmaking server.First of all, my feelings toward this game are mostly positive. I love the general gameplay style, it's like Smash Bros meeting MOBAs like Dota and LoL, 2D and stuff.Music, oh boy, Sonic Picnic has really given their best with the game's soundtrack.Visuals, they're great, I love the 1980's cartoon style Ronimo has been going for, same goes for the characters and lore in general.Ronimo keeps updating the game with more characters, visual and gameplay advancements, new features such as new bots you can play with, when not having players in game, new game modes in custom games, skins and announcers. It's the reason the game is still going on for it's 3rd year on Steam, has got PS4 release that is also updated from time to time, and Xbox One -version coming.Community involvement is great thing with this game, as I myself have made some sort of "career" on YouTube somewhat because of Awesomenauts. We've walked the path of YouTube together for these +2 years. And I thank both this game and it's developers with cooperation :) Also, the community of players might sometimes feel childish etc, but there are a lot of smart people who strive to keep Awesomenauts, well, awesome. We have had some great tournaments and other events, our suggestion for character voice lines, skin and/or character ideas are passed down to the game in one form or another, and in example, Replays have given us options to make more different kinds of gameplay videos to YouTube.Of course, this game has it's issues. Since Ronimo can't afford to rewrite the netcode for Awesomenauts to enable dedicated servers, players have to deal with P2P, which will cause problems if 1. Player/players have faulty connection and/or 2. players involved are from different countries. Of course you can limit the options your matchmaking queue goes for, but it's a bit flawed until Ronimo implements their new Matchmaking servers around the release of Overdrive expansion (which isn't required to use the matchmaking servers, mind you). Connection problems aren't fixed by that, but at least matchmaking will be more "fair" towards players of different skill levels and you are less likely to be put in a game against players from other side of the world.Speaking of skill levels, new players might find problems to start the game if they skip beginner missions and jump right into the online games (which is not recommended). Skill level might vary even in the higher leagues of leaderboards, but there are cases that new players quit the game because they don't feel the need of commitment to learn the basics and advanced techniques of the game and it's characters.Then there's character balance. Some characters are already pretty balanced in a sense, but then there are one's that are doomed to be bad or too good. But, balancing acharacter isn't a walk on a sunshine, it's like stacking a house of cards. One slip and the whole house of cards might collapse, of course, then you have to start over again, but once you get it right, man, it feels satisfying. Even though you're missing couple of cards, which in this game are incoming characters and maps.But, my likes, which are plenty, clearly overpower the dislikes towards this game, and over 2000 hours in the game, I say that I love this game. I believe that Ronimo can and will strive to make this game stand out and stay alive for a long time, and I'm willing to stay with Ronimo until the day Awesomenauts has to move to a higher plane of existence.For about 10 euros (and hefty amount of sales/giveaways you can get this game from) this game is worth your time for at least those 10 hours. DLCs are mostly skins and announcers, and the Starstorm Expansion, but even without those you can get some solid hours in to this game. It's also great with friends, be it normal games or Custom games. With the upcoming matchmaking servers, Overdrive Expansion with three new characters, not to mention free character Ix the Interloper from the 2nd Design-a-naut contest and Starstorm station map AND character art updates for older characters, this game gets the love it deserves from the company who made it, and it should get the love it deserves from you, too.Buy it. Play it. NOW!

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												In a MOBA, there are typically levels. You level up and your stats increase, and you usually gain a large amount of money. Now imagine that you're playing LoL, DOTA 2, whatever your choice MOBA is. Imagine that when you get a kill, your entire team gets a huge amount of EXP and money. More than you would get if you had the best possible CS(Creep Score) at that point in the game. This is what Awesomenauts decided to do with the EXP system. Upon killing an enemy(which will happen before one team even reaches level 1),  the team's shared EXP shoots through the roof, giving ~1.5 levels. For this level up, the team gets a large amount of Solar(the game's currency, used to buy items), and their base stats increase, namely HP and Attack. Before this EXP system, there was no way to get stronger but by purchasing items. This added a level of depth to the flow of the game, as leaving to buy items was a time-consuming process. You gambled everytime you decided to stay out after killing an enemy, chanced that you would still be strong enough to take on your enemy, who had just bought items. Leaving at the wrong time could cause your turrets or teammates to be decimated by the larger enemy force. By playing your cards right, you could turn the entire game on it's head during these times, defeating foes as a team that you would usually lose to by yourself, or boldly attacking turrets head-on when no enemies were around. This, however, could make games a little longer. And 40 minutes might seem like a normal game of any other MOBA, but for Awesomenauts, that was loooooong, because typical games were 25 minutes, and that was with plenty of back-and-forth. The creators of the game, however, wanted to make games shorter. It's an appealing concept, but Awesomenauts was already very, very fast-paced. I never noticed that 25 minutes had passed, because there was just so much to do, and the possibility of coming back after a team-clearing battle was entirely possible. Awesomenauts was a game that made you interested, and you wanted to be focused, because even if you messed up, even if your K/D was 0-10, you could still win, you could still be the underdog that came from nowhere with a sneaky play and stole the game.Some new characters(namely Rocco) ruined this aspect. You now had Ashe in the form of a bird, and he could hit you through turrets, from his own spawn. He could teleport back and fire an arrow to ward off or even kill enemies that were going after turrets. Coming back wasn't the most viable thing in the world now. But it was still entirely possible.And then they introduced the EXP system. At first, I was intrigued. Some characters were quite hard to get going at the start of a game, even if you got first blood. So I was hoping this would rectify that, and balance out some of the "late-blooming" characters. I was wrong. The EXP system changed the game from this mysterious, complex game of back-and-forth into a game where first blood was all that mattered. A game where one slip-up, a little bit of lag leading you to get killed meant that you lost the game for your team. The game was not forgiving anymore, bending to the way of skilled players who may have died once or twice in a game, but was now rigid, placing a wall between the team who didn't get first blood and any shot at victory. Some people might like this new system, it does turn the first 1-3 minutes of every game into a toss-up, and makes those >3 minutes really tense. But after someone gets a kill, it's just a matter of watching that team win over the next 5-10 minutes. So, if you like games where one teammate or a single slip-up costs you the entire game, buy it. But if you want a game where anyone can come back, the underdog can win, and the game is determined by not just skill in a single kill, but skill over an entire game, in strategy and observation?You missed it. It's gone. And I'm sorry you missed it, because it was easily the best MOBA I've ever played. The community loved the game, and the game loved the community. I'm refunding this game because it's not the game I paid for, all that time ago. It's a 3-minute game, with a toxic community due to a new system that places blame squarely on an individual player for a loss. Thanks for the good times, Awesomenauts. But I guess the best things never last.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												Is this game fun, Well yes. BUT there are somethings that need to change in order for this game to truely be a good game. Pros.The game perfectly captures the moba spirit, but in a fast paced action platformer. Don't like RTS style constant clicking? Think there's not enough action in Dota or league of legends? This game has it.Voice acting and soundtrack are great.artstyle is nice and freshThe game IS fun.Negatives.This game can not be competitive yet. There are numerous reasons why, but let's start off with the worst offenders.1. There is no strategy to picking a character. None. There isn't a draft, so you can't see what the other team is going to pick. It's like Blind pick in league of legends. There's a reason for that mode not being ranked. If the other team happens to pick a character that counters yours, you're screwed the entire game. I propose something like league of legends. Each team can ban 1 character, and they take turns picking their characters while the one they picked is shown to both teams. Until this is implemented, If you are looking for a serious competition, go look elsewhere.2. The Paywall.What Paywall? The expansion. I'm fine with them having an expansion. That isn't the issue. Here's the issue. Almost all of the expansion characters have a attack that passes through the turrets. Normally, you can use the turret as a shield to take some damage while you fight off the enemy team. A lot of the characters in the expansion have attacks that can go through said turret. nibbs, Penny, Ted McPain (in levels that have the turrets on top of the jungle area), sentry x58 has an attack that draws you in from behind the turret. You see where I'm going with this? Ok. So there are characters that can get you behind the turret. There must be one that can in the normal game too, right? Yeah, there is. One. Coco. So if you have the expansion, you can poke the heck out of anyone behind the turret, but if you just have the base game? Just pray there's a coco on your team or you're screwed because you can't touch them. 3. Joining late games.The game has bots take over after someone leaves. That's awesome and well needed in other mobas. You know what isn't awesome? Other players can then join the game and replace these bots. I've had numerous times where I'd join a game, only to find out all the turrets were gone for us and the whole team had rage quit so I'm the only one there. A garenteed lose. Gee, thanks. Unfortunately this happens WAY to often. You get screwed just for wanting to play the game! If people still want that feature, fine. Put a switch in there that you can click and say "I only want to join NEW games. NOT games in progress." This sucks.4. Disconnections. The game gives you a penalty for quiting the game. This is good. Unfortunately, You can't rejoin games that you have disconnected from. Internet goes down for a second? Congrats, you are now punished when you start another game.  Game crashes? Punished. Fair, right? You should be able to rejoin games that you we disconnected from. Simple as that.Summary:This game is fun. I always have a good match or two when playing. But, because of these problems, I can't recommend this game. These issues need to be fixed before this game is good enough to recommend to anyone.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
IntroductionThe review for this game is in the game's title; Awesome!Awesomenauts is a unique, 2D MOBA that brings together old-school platforming, realtime action and overall fun. While it might not be as competitive as other MOBAs (like Dota or LoL), it's a great game that's easy to learn but hard to master. Filled with unique and interesting characters, Awesomenauts has kept me playing for hours on end. Positives Creative, innovative take on conventional MOBA-styled games. Charming, unique characters that all play differently. Amazing soundtrack and artstyle. Responsive controls. Developers are amazing, and work very hard to keep the game balanced and fun. Encourages team-based gameplay. Really fun for friends to play together. Great community, with loads of artwork, mods and guides. A lot of replayability (Just look at how many hours I've played.)Negatives No dedicated servers, so there's sometimes lag. Matchmaking a little unpredictable (but it is being worked on!) Allows players to leave mid-game without good consequence. Can be frustrating at times.ConclusionAwesomenauts it's a really fun, action-packed game that encourages teamwork and strategy. It's a game you can tell was built with love and heart, from not just the developers, but also the community. Personally, I would (and have) recommend this to anyone who's just looking for a fun time!

												I'm updating my review to reflect the new Awesomenauts content since my review 4 years ago.LEVEL EDITORThis update is incredible. Taking a game like this and allowing the community to create their own designs, and even upload custom textures has so many possibilities. I'm currently working on my own map and it's the most satisfaction I've got from this game in a while. Hopefully the devs continue supporting the Steam Workshop for this game and it blossoms into something greater than its ever been.DLCI'm really glad the devs are still supporting the game, but I hope they stop selling character packs. I believe all of the characters should be free and accessible to new players, and I think this paywall is deterring new people. I also think the base game should be free to play, or at least have a permanent price reduction. I would think the cosmetic DLC options would keep the devs afloat, especially if lowering the cost of the base game attracts new players (aka customers).GAMEOne final note, the game holds up. It offers a slew of characters since the original 6 at launch. I think we're at 29 now? It's fun, fast paced 3v3 action with your friends or against AI (not to mention a lot of the AI was made by the community). I've heard the online matchmaking can be a pain for people outside EU or NA, but I hope the devs can expand the player base to mitigate this issue (going back to my F2P option). I'm surprised they've captured and kept my intrigue since launch back in 2012, and I hope it continues for years to come.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
 At a glance   Game Name:   Awesomenauts  Original Release:  1 August 2012  Genre Tags:  MOBA, Multiplayer, Platformer, 2D, RTS.   My Overall Grade:  B+  Estimated Playtime:  20-35 minutes each round and maybe more.   Multiplayer Aspect:  Auxiliary   Recommended To:  Established fans of the genre; those intrigued by the genre; Dota Players.   Review  Thinking of the MOBA it might sounds like a plodding war of attrition with particular hero characters between traditional battle roles, like tank, healer, ranged, and damage dealer. The game is simple, each team have to push against waves of human players or their AI sidekicks (if less player); whichever bunch gets through the other side first takes home the win. Turret situations, summon spots bring forth extra help, and concealed ways permit players to flank their enemies. Awesomenauts fabricates an intricate layer of system around a no frills 2D center, and this is the place attentive players will find brilliant strategies.Each character has a unique set of skills, consisting of a free-use weapon and two special actions. As the player acquires Solar, they can return to their base to heal and spend the Solar on various upgrades to these skill sets or core statistics such as movement speed and health. For each of four areas: the two special skills, their free weapon, and general statistics, the player can selected to buy up to three of six available improvements, with some improvements which can be bought multiple times with benefits stacked.Awesomenauts is like a mini version of Dota !

												Sadly, I am going to have to agree with many of the other reviewers here. The new XP system has broken the game. I'm all for making moves to increase game speed, but this move makes games impossible or incredibly easy, depending on how the dice roll for you at match making. If you have a leaver and a bot fills in until another player can be found, you're out of luck. The other team will quickly overtake you in damage, even if you play flawlessly. Have a feeder? He WILL lose you the game, and there is nothing you can do. The last game I played, I was 6-0, doing pretty well. I was completely maxed on upgrades. Unfortunately, I had a team member who fed a bit, and we started out with a bot for the first 5 minutes. Try as I might, no matter how many times I bested the other team and pushed them into a retreat, they would simply pick up a kill from one of my team mates and bide their time. Eventually, they rushed our base, and there was nothing I could do.I would have picked this game over any other MOBA before trying it with the new patch. Now, I'm not so sure.

Posted: January 4
												I can only recommend if the devs have one last sensible decision up their sleeve to bring in more players.As of January 2017 the game has "better" matchmaking. However the games biggest problem IMO is the size of the player base.  You can get decent games at peak time in Europe (and North America I presume). But I can't imagine this being the case in the rest of the world. I wish this game could copy the F2P system of the MOBA SMITE where you can get all characters for free by earning points from playing matches or pay a one off fee for instant access to every existing character and all future ones but I'm no business man and I understand Awesomenauts is an indie game with limited staff. I'm sure the company behind SMITE have a ton of people pumping out the paid costumes and free content for their title.Awesomenauts is a 2D game with fairly simple graphics so I would guess it takes less work.Could Awesomenauts survive on paid costumes? The game regularly goes on sale for a lower price than many of the premium costumes so I don't see why it can't just go F2P already. I have a friend who has spent well over £1000 on SMITE a F2P game... You see my point? Even if the game goes on sale for ~£2 it's still a huge barrier for people to just try out the game, get hooked and buy lots of costumes. I haven't spent a dime on SMITE granted but if the game has hundreds of thousands of players there's going to be plenty who will buy costumes (there are a lot of cool costumes might I add).I did give £30 to the Starstorm kickstarter for this game, I've bought a few costumes for my favourite characters and I am probably going to buy the latest "expansion" reluctantly. But that's because I really like the game.This game has good potential but that is wavering. We need dedicated servers. We need the option to invest our time to earn characters for free. I won't feel betrayed if all the game and paid characters I bought suddenly become free just let us who paid for the game get the next few instantly.Be smart and don't let it die Ronimo!

content:
Posted: November 18, 2013
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below) Game Name: Awesomenauts Original Release: 2012 Genre Tags: 2D; MOBA; Platformer; Multiplayer   My Overall Grade: A Estimated Playtime (Campaign): N/A Multiplayer Aspect: Primary Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Multiplayer gamers REVIEWAwesomenauts is a simplistic and fun little MOBA that has a moderate learning curve and is mostly easy to get the hang of.  It isn’t as complex or competitive as many other MOBAs out there. This is a good thing for anyone who wants to play some PVP without having to deal with an overly complicated game and an overly angry playerbase.The game plays out in matches on small 2D arena-like maps.  At the start of each match, the players can choose from several Awesomenauts (read: heroes) to play as, each with their own different abilities.  Each match takes about a half hour or so, as two teams push with “creeps” to destroy towers and the enemy base. Sound familiar? So it plays like a traditional MOBA, but in 2D.The combination of the distinctiveness of 2D MOBA combat and the well-designed abilities for the different Awesomenauts creates a pretty enjoyable gameplay experience. It is fun to play around with the different character combinations to see what fun you can have with the unique gameplay. Also, there is a pretty decent playerbase and the developers have consistently been updating the game and creating new content, so it appears to have a stable heartbeat.Awesomenauts would be a good game to consider if you are someone who is interested in playing a PVP game for fun and don’t want to deal with the hostility of the community of other MOBAs. The ranking system does its best to keep everyone around where they should win 50% of the time. But that doesn’t stop some people from believing they should be winning every single match; luckily they’re the minority in this game. Due to the simplicity of the mechanics and the lighthearted nature of the game, the community tends to be a little less unnecessarily competitive than in other games.EDIT: As of the start of the year 2016, it has been a while since I have played this. The developers have continued to support the game with updates. I cannot speak about the current state of certain aspects of the game which may have changed since I have last played, but I believe what I have said here still holds true to the core game.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												Awesomenauts is a 2D "MOBA" game that pits two teams of three against each other.  It has all of the trappings you've come to expect from your dota clones: XP, gold, buying, mindless drones running in lanes, turrets, bases, and trash-talking players.  The characters are all unique and have really interesting designs.  I love how there's themes for each character.  Every win, if you can manage to secure one, is accompanied by a chorus of singers belting out a short stinger of "The Awesomenats!" that doesn't get old.  Alas...This game might have been fun to play when it was released when there were more players.  As it stands now, the player base has diminished and the only people playing are the diehards who have hundreds, if not thousands of hours in the game.  There is no room for newbies here, which unfortunately precludes me from truly enjoying the game.  I have received my fair share of insults and trash talk from both teammates and opponents alike.Like all "MOBA" games, the small team sizes (even smaller than the usual 5v5) puts a tremendous amount of pressure on the individual to perform.  Having a weak link on the team is a death sentence, but that may go without saying to those familiar with "MOBA" games.At the time of writing, there is a single expansion pack out that contains 5 new characters with another expansion on the way.  Unable to play them myself, I cannot make a completely accurate judgment.  However, being subjected to enemy teams composed of these DLC characters, I find them extremely potent when compared to the vanilla characters.The second expansion, which apparently required a Kickstarter, promises 5 additional characters, an extra map, and a replay system.  With a game that struggles to maintain 1000 concurrent players, it's probably too little too late.I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this game to anyone.  There are plenty of other games that are worth your time and attention.  This isn't one of them.

number of helpful: 12 of 18 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2013
												The fun and beauty of Awesomenauts lies in it delivering the MOBA experience found in games such as DOTA, but at a far more casual and beginner-friendly level. Just as with DOTA, the idea of the game is to destory turrets across numerous "lanes" to get to the opponent team's boss structure. Autonomous creeps are spawned from each team that attack the other team's structures, with the player commanding a hero that grows more powerful as the game progresses. Unlike most traditional MOBAs which are in 3D, Awesomenauts takes on a simpler 2D form reminiscent of platformer games. Games typically span 20 minutes and pit teams of 3 Nauts against each other.Instead of over 80 heroes in DOTA, there is only a small pool of 10+ Nauts to choose from. There is also no need to delve into the nitty-gritty of what items to buy or what stats/skills to train - the skill tree of the Nauts is far more simple. Other elements such as warding, lasthitting, denying, creep pulling etc. are also left out. That is not to say there is zero depth to the game. Individual player skill and teamwork remain of prime importance to ensure victory just as with any other MOBA. Some Nauts have a fairly high skill cap and various synergies which help add to the strategic element of the game - all this under a deceptively simple facade where each Naut only has two skills.The artwork is crisp and colorful, with no disorienting clutter during teamfights. Other notable upsides to the game are its fairly large and active community (with at least 1000 players ingame at any moment, finding a game is easy) and a ranking system. There is no pay-to-win, with all heroes being unlockable and any additional purchases being cosmetic only.Downsides to this game would be that associated with almost any MOBA - balance issues. This is especially pertinent when the hero pool is small - overpowered Nauts make the game less fun for everyone else. Another major problem is that the game automatically fills empty slots with bots, which typically do little other than feed the enemy gold. Furthermore, there is little disincentive for a player to leave a game if they are losing, which perpetuates the problem of *most* games being one-sided stomps against a full party of bots at the end.Despite this, Awesomenauts remains a fun game at heart, especially if you play it with friends.

number of helpful: 12 of 18 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												Awesomenauts is a 3v3 MOBA-style 2D platformer where each player takes control of one unique Awesomenaut and battle with the other team to push their turrets, destroy them, and ultimately destroy their base.The gameplay is your typical MOBA with a twist in that it's a platformer as well, making it a pretty interesting combination. Besides your typical knowledge about characters, their specializations and skills, you will also need some platforming experience as well, especially that certain characters have different movement abilities than others (certain are even capable of flight). It's action-packed and fun, but very hard to grasp and often turns into an unreadable chaotic mess due to the sheer amount of stuff that is going on at the same time.Graphic-wise, the special effects look nice, and all the characters have their own general style, though they all are pretty cartoonish and sometimes a little cheesy. It does add a bit to their charm, however.The music is, for the lack of better wording, awesome. Each character has their own musical theme (which also plays if you get a killstreak) and all of them are a good listen, especially that they cover a lot od different styles and genres, like Clunk's metal or Voltar's classical orchestra.So, on the surface the game feels nice, but the problems begin piling up when you go play online.The first thing is the horrible supposedly skill-based matchmaking. I say supposedly as it only operates on a league system, with each player being given a number, 1 being the highest, and 9 being the lowest in skill. The main two flaws are the fact that leagues reset every two months, so the first one or two weeks after the reset newbies are very likely to encounter skilled players who will absolutely stomp them to the ground, and the other is that the matchmaker has no problem teaming you up with a premade team consisting of Prestige 10 players (who reset and regained their levels a total of ten times) when you're new to the game, which, unless some kind of a miracle happens, will most likely result in a complete steamroll.It also doesn't help that the balance changes are made on a constant basis and while this is good in general, it also makes most user-made guides outdated pretty fast, so you're effectively stuck with the general description of character's role and abilities, and maybe a friend's help when it comes to learning the game, and considering it's a MOBA platformer, it's not only pretty harsh at the start, but also very easy to lose against veterans.The game does put up a certain "Difficulty" rating on each 'Naut, either Easy, Medium or Hard, but it's honestly far from correct. For example, it labels Coco as "Easy" even though she relies very heavily on mobility and correct use of her abilities instead of just whacking things in the head with your weapon, while at the same time calling Swiggins "Hard" despite his abilities being rather straightforward and generally easy to use.There are also certain Starstorm-exclusive 'Nauts where I can barely stop myself from calling them "pay to win" (mostly looking at Nibbs), so I am going to use a more generally accepted term of "horribly skill-gated and not fun to play against unless you know the exact way to counter them".When it comes to the expansion itself, it kind of does not help my opinion about the developer when they already begin to collect preorders for the next expansion, Overdrive, when they didn't even release everything associated with the Starstorm expansion (namely its exclusive map). Generally speaking you should finish the content people already paid for before moving on to create content for a separate purchase, unless you want people to look at you a bit shadily. Doesn't help that despite the beta the new heroes were overpowered as hell and often relied on cheap tactics, and the promised matchmaker rebalance still matches up newbies versus veterans. To the developer's credit, however, they do release some free updates for everyone every few months.Overall, this is a fun at its core, but very difficult to master and incredibly demotivating at start game. Personally, I just can't get myself into it big-time. Badly-designed matchmaker, a lot of things being far from obvious at first, and certain characters being just way too tricky to counter effectively while being generally easy to use if you're new to the game, and newly-released ones being overpowered or even P2W if they're DLC, are some of the factors that kill it for me. It's not a bad game, just one that's ridiculously difficult to learn at start and where the high skill ceiling makes it pretty much impossible to play casually unless you restrict yourself to bot matches.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												This game used to be really good, but ever since the game made an update where everyone's level is combined, it has went downhill. You are on a team of 3 people, let's just say that two of you guys are doing good, but one person on the team is doing bad, you will lose, because that team member that keeps dying, is giving the other team a bunch of levels and upgrades. This is probably one of the only team based multiplayer game that I know of where one team member can impact the other two team members that much. Not only that, this is the most unbalanced multiplayer competitive game that I have played.There are certain characters that are just mismatches. What I mean by that is that some characters are just weak against other characters, kind of like Pokemon. If you want to win any matches at all, you have to use the overpowered characters, like the recent DLC characters.  Before DLC characters were implemented into the game, there were a few unfair, or overpowered characters, but after DLC characters, the game just became pay to win. Yes, you pay for DLC and you will win matches, guaranteed. I used to like this game because I thought it was unique, and it really stood out on Steam, however all of the updates that the developers have made to this game has changed it to DLC, Pay to win, unbalanced mess. All in all, I do not recommend this game to anyone.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												[EDIT] This isn't even the game that I payed for any more. I've given these people money over and over again and instead of getting what I originally payed for they took it away and made into something else entirely. I'm not even angry any more, just upset, like what I thought was the unreasonable behavior of a loved one was just the early symptoms of terminal brain cancer.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------This was a great game that provided hours of fun and entertainment, truly reminding me of Saturday mornings as a little kid. Emphasis on the was. This game was easily my favorite MOBA that I ever encountered, until Ronimo fell for the trap of "listening" to the fans. The frequent hotfixes and character stat changes have left the game damn near unplayable, taking mains or other characters you enjoy playing as and completely changing how they feel, even completely changing skills/abilities.The last straw for me was not even the unbalanced Starstorm characters (which I backed on Kickstarter, something I now regret entirely), but rather patch 2.10, which has effectively turned Voltar, the only straight up healer in the game and a solid contender for one of the best supports in any multiplayer game, into a useless squishy blob with no pushing capabilites, no speed, no maneuveribility, and most importantly, an ineffective medic. The one mechanic that was changed to improve him was his increase in DPS for his Drone ability, which works- for anything left completely alone or an afk player, because his drones will actively target everything on the map other than actual threats coming up on top of you.Buy this game on sale, it goes for 90% fairly often, but don't expect to be playing this game for more than a couple of weeks- the magic will wear off and you'll find yourself left with a mediocre game that doesn't know what it wants to be, and never will as a long as Ronimo keeps on addressing problems that the vocal few "fans" keep bringing up, instead of taking a good hard look at the product and figuring out what needs to change.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
-Quick Review-Awesomenauts is a 2D MOBA (Multiplayer online battle arena), with a strong sense of progression, and a lot of different dynamics that can be taken into account. I don't really have anything negative to say about the game, read on if you want to know more specifics! -Detailed breakdown review-Story:  Two sides are at war, choose your awesomenaut and ship out and defeat the other team! As you would expect from a game based completely on battling there isn't much to explain about the story, there is a nice opening cinematic that has a hilarious similar to a Power Rangers episode, but other than that the game is mostly an exchange of  going back and forward fighting indefinitely.Game Play: The controls are best explained while playing the game. the movement is ASDW, you can use W or space to jump, some characters have a double jump, some fly. You use both mouse buttons and the scroll lock click to use various abilities. The button configuration is very toned down, you're limited on what abilities you can use, and before you start the game you select the abilities you want to unlock as you play the game.Okay, now I should say something about the various characters, there are A LOT of characters which might compliment your play style. I tried them all while playing "offline practice mode", I found my favorite character and then intended to play as that character until I became very familiar with the game.As you play through the game (even playing offline practice mode) you will received experience that will unlock new awesomenauts and abilities for your awesomenauts. This element in the game gives me a very strong sense of progression throughout the game. (coupled with getting a lot of easy-to-earn-achievements that I earned while playing offline! (Thank you for that Awesomenauts!)I keep talking about "offline practice mode", the reason I do is because I spent a lot of time playing in this mode before starting the game. When I first played this game I tried to play it with my friend, we were both equally noobish at what was going on, I didn't even know this was a MOBA! So naturally we got ourselves massacred. :( Left a bad taste in my mouth......But! after I discovered offline practice mode, I learned on my own without looking up guides how I wanted to play the game. Naturally if I wanted to get better guides would help, but I like to think I'm a fairly competent gamer, playing offline let me try out various characters and strategies without dragging down my team. You can adjust the AI to make practice easier or more difficult depending on your confidence.A final note about playing through the game, you start the game out with "solar" or "coins", you collect more of these from killing various npc / players, as you collect more, you return to your base to purchase upgrades for your awesomenaut making him/her stronger. knowing which ones to upgrade and which ones to select take practice, guides, or strategy. Once again, if you want to actually learn the game, try out offline practice mode to see what I mean! :D Achievements: I got a bit ahead of myself earlier with a note about the achievements. They were mostly straightforward:  Win games, play games, taunt your enemy, go on a crazy killing spree, hoard up Solar (in-game currency) and then the rest are pretty much grind grind grind. Grind creep kills, grind turret kills, grind online game wins.Most of the simple achievements are simple, most of the grinding achievements you should just play the game to enjoy the game, let those grindy achievements happen if they happen. That is Atratzu's suggestion for this game's achievements. Price: Awesomenauts costs $9.99, So far (08/16/14) I've played 5.7 hours. I've really enjoyed learning how the game works, but my "value system" dictates that I need to spend at least 9 hours in the game to make it worth-my-while. I definitely think this game has that type of replay-ability.As always, I recommend buying games when they're on sale, or getting them in humble bundles, I was given this game as a gift from one of my friends (You know who you are). And we haven't gotten around to playing together, but this game would really be fun to play with friends. Conclusion: Coming into this review, I knew from the start that I didn't really have anything negative to say about the game. *IF* there was one thing I would like to have in the game that I didn't have, I would like to play offline practice with my friends over steam, but that doesn't take away from the game in any way.Once again, story was "meh" but amusing, game play was "engaging different and fun", achievements were "okay", and the price was "fair". I recommend this game to anyone who likes 2D platformers, and competitive battle games. If you would like to play it sometime with me, you're welcome to do so; I intend to continue playing this game over time. I really enjoyed it.
